headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2010 NiSource Earnings Conference Call. My name is Danielle, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for tod
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2010 NiSource Earnings Conference Call. My name is Danielle, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Mr. Glen Kettering, Senior Vice President of Corporate Affairs. Please proceed.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you and good morning. On behalf of NiSource, I'd like to welcome you to our Quarterly Analyst Call. Joining me this morning are Bob Skaggs, President and Chief Executive Officer; Steve Smith, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and
componenttext:
Thank you and good morning. On behalf of NiSource, I'd like to welcome you to our Quarterly Analyst Call. Joining me this morning are Bob Skaggs, President and Chief Executive Officer; Steve Smith, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Randy Hulen, Managing Director of Investor Relations.
As you know, the focus of today's call is to review our financial performance for the fourth quarter and full year of 2010 and to provide a business update. We'll then open the call to your questions. At times during the call, we will refer to the supplemental slides available on our website at www.nisource.com.
I'd like to remind you that some of the statements made in this conference call will be forward-looking statements. These statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed in the statements. Information concerning such risks and uncertainties is included in the MD&A and Risk Factors sections of our periodic SEC filings.
And now, I'd turn the call over to Bob Skaggs.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Glen. Good morning and thanks for joining us. Today we'll cover several key points before opening the line to your questions. First, I'll address NiSource's strong overall performance for 2010. As you can see, the team once again delivered financi
componenttext:
Thanks, Glen. Good morning and thanks for joining us. Today we'll cover several key points before opening the line to your questions. First, I'll address NiSource's strong overall performance for 2010. As you can see, the team once again delivered financial results in line with our earnings guidance while taking significant steps towards meeting customer needs, creating shareholder value and generating long-term sustainable earnings growth. 
I'll also touch on the foundational actions state taking during 2010 to strengthen NiSource's financial profile and enhance our ability to find a wide array of attractive infrastructure modernization and growth investment opportunities. And finally, I'll outline our 2011 earnings guidance, which reflects our continued commitment to sustainable earnings growth and underscores the underlying strength of NiSource's core businesses and the markets that we serve.
So first, let's turn to our 2010 results. For the year, we continued to see positive customer benefits, enhanced shareholder value and sustainable earnings growth from NiSource's well-established infrastructure investment driven strategy. During 2010, our team executed on a broad array of key regulatory and financial initiatives, infrastructure enhancement programs and new growth projects. 
These achievements, combined with improved margins and increased usage in our industrial electric markets, enabled us to deliver on our earnings commitments for the fourth consecutive year. For 2010, that means delivering earnings squarely in line with the increased non-GAAP range of $1.20 to $1.25 per share that we provided when we reported earnings for the third quarter. And notably, we achieved these results while remaining responsive to needs of our customers and other key stakeholders.
On Slide 3 of the supplemental slides, you can see that NiSource delivered 2010 net operating earnings non-GAAP of about $340 million or $1.22 per share compared to $1.07 per share last year, representing a 14% increase over 2009. Our earnings release and supplemental slides spell out the details regarding our improved 2010 results. 
But here are just a few highlights. We saw materially improved industrial margins and usage in our Electric business which helped boost operating earnings by more than $50 million over 2009. In addition, our Gas Distribution infrastructure enhancement and regulatory initiatives helped generate more than $50 million in added revenues. In our Gas Pipeline and Storage business, the successful completion of growth project helped increase demand margin revenues by more than $20 million over 2009. Despite the fact that a number of our projects were in service for only a portion of the year. These results reflect core strength of our business plan, the focus of our team as well as continued signs of resilience in our key markets.
Going forward, I'm convinced that NiSource's established infrastructure investment driven strategy will continue to generate positive results for our company, our customers and our investors. We remain committed to this strategy and are focused on executing it in a disciplined, thoughtful manner.
Turning to Slide 4, this slide highlights several key initiatives Steve Smith and our finance team completed during 2010. These efforts significantly strengthened our financial profile and position us to fund our compelling array of infrastructure investment opportunities. 
Most notably in September we completed a $400 million equity offering. This offering, which was structured as a forward sell arrangement, aligns with and strongly supports our targeted annual capital investment level, which I'm pleased to note for 2011 is targeted up to $1.1 billion. In addition, in December, we successfully tendered nearly $275 million in debt and concurrently executed a 30-year debt offering of $250 million. 
This will reduce our interest expense by about $10 million in 2011 and extend the maturity of our debt profile. Of course we also remain true to our key financial commitments to preserve our stable investment grade credit rating and maintain our attractive secure dividend, all while delivering long-term earnings growth.
With the successful completion of our equity offering and other key elements of financial strategy, NiSource's well-positioned to take advantage of the deep inventory of investment opportunities available across our business portfolio and continue growing our business and earnings on a sustainable basis.
Before turning to our 2011 outlook, let me on just some of the key business accomplishments that play such a key role in advancing our business strategy. 
First and foremost, we continue to see solid progress in Indiana. Jimmy Staton and his NIPSCO team are taking significant steps to improve customer service and reliability while addressing a number of important regulatory matters. In November, NIPSCO filed a new electric rate case with the Indiana Utility Regulatory Commission or IURC. 
While filed in November, the preparation and stakeholder outreach and engagement for the case began long before that. The result is a proposal that is balanced and responsive to both the needs of the company and our customers and other constituencies. We'll continue to engage with all stakeholders and expect the case to be completed during 2011. As we mentioned in today's release and have discussed in past updates, we expect to restore NIPSCO's earnings to a reasonable and appropriate level by the beginning of 2012.
Also, in November, NIPSCO received IURC approval of the unanimous settlement of its 2010 natural gas rate case, the company's first in 20 years. The settlement resulted in an overall rate decrease for customers while enhancing the company's operating earnings. It also improved rate design and continued our strong support for low-income assistance, energy efficiency and conservation.
Last but not least, following IURC certificate of approval at the end of December, NIPSCO is launching a major environmental upgrade in our Schaeffer generating station, which will contribute to the company's earnings growth going forward. This is the first phase of a series of the environmental investments in Indiana, totaling about $600 million over the next six to eight years. These initiatives are fully in line with NIPSCO's new source review settlement with the EPA that we announced earlier this year.
Turning to our NiSource's Gas Transmission & Storage business on Slide 7. Chris Helm and his team are continuing to capitalize on NiSource's unparalleled geographic footprint to complete and advance customer driven growth projects primarily in the Marcellus Shale production area. During 2010, NGT&S put in service or nearly completed more than $150 million in strategic growth projects serving the Marcellus shale production area. These products provide market access for more than 500,000 decatherms of natural gas daily. 
Our $80 million Majorsville series of projects served as a cornerstone of an array of additional projects currently in process across the Marcellus play. Progress also continued on our Columbia Gulf Transmission rate case for the federal energy regulatory commission. The following increased revenues of approximately $50 million per year, reflecting updated cost and operating conditions. new rate go into effect subject to refund starting this May.
As I noted earlier, growth project revenues were up by more than $20 million in NGT&S in 2010 and for projects such as Majorsville, we've not yet experienced a full year's earnings run rate. Having said that, overall operating earnings for the year were down due to anticipated expense increases, pension and integrity management in particular and reduced short-term transportation revenue resulting from a lack of natural gas price volatility. 
Looking forward, we remain enthusiastic NGT&S earnings growth prospects for 2011 and beyond driven by accretive infrastructure investments which we expect to amount to about $200 million annually.
Turning to our third major business unit, NiSource Gas Distribution or NGD. Our NGD teams continue to execute our strategy of combining long-term infrastructure replacement programs with complementary regulatory initiatives. 
Millions of customers are benefiting from this strategy, which includes significant revenue producing facility modernization programs at our largest utilities, Columbia Gas of Ohio, Columbia Gas of Pennsylvania and Columbia Gas of Massachusetts. In aggregate, these programs provide NGD with an investment opportunity approaching $4.5 billion over the next 20 to 25 years. On the regulatory front in December, Columbia Gas of Virginia received approval from the Virginia State Corporation Commission of a unanimous settlement of its first base rate case in 12 years. 
The settlement authorized a $5 million revenue increase as well as a number of rate design and other enhancements. The new rates took effect January 1. And in mid-January, Columbia Gas of Pennsylvania filed a new rate case with the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission. That case seeks recovery of ongoing infrastructure investments, a modernized rate structure, as well as new senior citizen and energy efficiency programs. Filing seeks an annual revenue increase of about $38 million.
Finally, I'd like to briefly outline our 2011 earnings guidance and key 2010 takeaways on Slide 8 before opening the line to your questions. Based on the continued success of our balanced business strategy and an extensive array of growth investment opportunities available across all of our businesses, we remain confident that NiSource will sustainably grow long term earnings in the range of 3% to 5% annually.
In fact in the near term, particularly as we execute a number of regulatory initiatives, our operating earnings growth may well exceed that longer-term percentage range. 
With that in mind, we expect NiSource's 2011 net operating earnings to fall within a range of $1.25 to $1.35 per share. As you know, this is a non-GAAP range. Consistent with last year's outlook due to the unpredictability of weather and other factors, we're not providing GAAP earnings guidance. I'll also note that our 2011 guidance continues to be premised on a relatively modest and gradual economic recovery across the markets we serve.
In closing, I'd like to acknowledge our team, our customers and our many business community partners for their support and engagement during the past year. We've made significant progress in our business plan during 2010, all built on a foundation of ongoing investment across all of our companies.  
This core strategy remains unchanged for 2011, with the notable enhancement of our ability to invest in our businesses by the steps taken over the last years. And I can assure you that our investment approach will remain disciplined and straightforward, focused on meeting our customer needs while building long-term value for our shareholders.
As always, we remain committed to communicating with our stakeholders in a transparent and timely manner regarding these and all of our efforts. Ongoing updates will be provided through our analyst calls and news releases posted on www.NiSource.com. Thank you for participating today and for your continued interest and support of NiSource. Now, Danielle, let's open the call to questions.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Bob, can you help give you some color with respect to where we are in the Indiana settlement with respect to, if we're looking at, I guess, new rates perhaps being effective beginning of 2012, since the IURC is going to need to approve that, does that sug
componenttext: Bob, can you help give you some color with respect to where we are in the Indiana settlement with respect to, if we're looking at, I guess, new rates perhaps being effective beginning of 2012, since the IURC is going to need to approve that, does that suggest the settlement's basically midyear, is that kind of the effective timing?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just the one key point on context for this case, we filed rate case under the commission's expedited rules processing guidelines. And the commission accepted that filing under those guidelines and in fact has established an expedited procedural schedule f
componenttext: Just the one key point on context for this case, we filed rate case under the commission's expedited rules processing guidelines. And the commission accepted that filing under those guidelines and in fact has established an expedited procedural schedule for the case, Paul, that would provide for a decision during the fourth quarter of 2011. So if this case is litigated, it would proceed along that schedule and we feel confident the commission would render a decision during the fourth quarter which would enable us to put rates into effect at the beginning of 2012. Now, again that context, our intent, our hope, our desire would be to try to settle this case. And as I've mentioned consistently, we put full core press during the first quarter into the second quarter to attempt to settle this before the other parties have to put there witnesses on the stand and subject them to cross examinations. So we're now on a window, we're engaged in the parties, we're going to work diligently to try to settle this prior to midyear.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: One other question off of the 2010 rate case was all about this sort of conservation and pension, and of course a host of more thorny issues for the 2008 case. The motion to vacate and sort of settlement discussion as it's ongoing right now, are most of t
componenttext: One other question off of the 2010 rate case was all about this sort of conservation and pension, and of course a host of more thorny issues for the 2008 case. The motion to vacate and sort of settlement discussion as it's ongoing right now, are most of the conversation with shippers on the 2010 issues or is it still sort of looking at it more holistically, shall we say a?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: More holistically in the sense that cost allocation is an issue that remains. And we've attempted in rate case to set a direction that would provide the parties an opportunity to compromise on cost allocation. But we believe that will continue to be the k
componenttext: More holistically in the sense that cost allocation is an issue that remains. And we've attempted in rate case to set a direction that would provide the parties an opportunity to compromise on cost allocation. But we believe that will continue to be the key challenge in resolving this case sooner rather than later. Just let me add, Carl, we continue to believe that the traditional cost of service rate base sorts of issues are straightforward.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: One last question if I could, so lots of moving parts there as always. As we look to 2011 guidance and we look to segment, clearly LDC should be doing well given some of the depreciation changes that have happened in NIPSCO gas, as we're kind of looking a
componenttext: One last question if I could, so lots of moving parts there as always. As we look to 2011 guidance and we look to segment, clearly LDC should be doing well given some of the depreciation changes that have happened in NIPSCO gas, as we're kind of looking at the pluses and minuses that are happening, like what happened to transportation, even though we have some good demand charge addition, the O&M kind of overwhelmed at least for a little while. Should we still be expecting a possible slide on a net basis in pipelines for 2011 before perhaps kicking up in 2012? I just want to be sort of on the look out if there's any particular unit that might in fact be sliding on an operating income basis.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: We expect all three units to perform well. NGT&S in particular, we expect a strong year. We have baked into the relatively conservative outlook on our optimization, short-term Transportation business at NGT&S. So we believe that hit is behind us. So again
componenttext: We expect all three units to perform well. NGT&S in particular, we expect a strong year. We have baked into the relatively conservative outlook on our optimization, short-term Transportation business at NGT&S. So we believe that hit is behind us. So again, all three units, Carl, ought to be performing quite well in 2011, that's the expectation.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: If I could just ask you a couple questions, first on the operating expenses at Gas Transmission and Storage operation. You guys talked about some of the headwinds you have there. So OpEx was I guess up about $32 million year-over-year, how is that the tre
componenttext: If I could just ask you a couple questions, first on the operating expenses at Gas Transmission and Storage operation. You guys talked about some of the headwinds you have there. So OpEx was I guess up about $32 million year-over-year, how is that the trend into 2011? Should we now expect that since some of those maintenance activities are down that, that number should turn down or is it going to be relatively flat?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: We believe the core reliability and integrity management expense will be, give or take, flat year-to-year. We think some of the headwinds we had with pension expense at NGT&S, if you'll recall, they are on a cash basis, they're not on a expense basis, and
componenttext: We believe the core reliability and integrity management expense will be, give or take, flat year-to-year. We think some of the headwinds we had with pension expense at NGT&S, if you'll recall, they are on a cash basis, they're not on a expense basis, and that's because of FERC treatment on the pension and debt rate. So again we believe that, that will flatten out as well.

componenttext: Yes, let me ask Steve to address that question.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. The accelerated depreciation was held in form the legislation passed here recently. Over the next couple of years, 2011, 2012, is going to provide between $300 million and $400 million of benefit over the next several years. So it is a timing
componenttext: Thanks, Bob. The accelerated depreciation was held in form the legislation passed here recently. Over the next couple of years, 2011, 2012, is going to provide between $300 million and $400 million of benefit over the next several years. So it is a timing mechanism. You'll recall that in 2011, we get 100% bonus depreciation and in 2012, we get 50% bonus depreciation. So we've taken a rough estimate at what we believe bonus depreciation will provide to us in 2011. And that's in between $150 million and $200 million. And that is reflected in the sources and uses statement for 2011.

componenttext: We've had -- it's a great question -- it provides us enhanced flexibility with which we're very pleased with. For guidance purposes, we're assuming that we would pull half of forward sales down at the end of the third quarter in 2011. But it's something that we look at routinely. And I guess I would point out again, it does provide us with a lot of additional flexibility.

componenttext: Yes, we're still watching the market very carefully. I think you may have heard me discuss before that debt of MLP given our circumstances is in question, that that's something we continue to bake. And right now, frankly, we don't think it fits. Having said that, we are not ignoring the performance of the MLP, we believe that it can be an attractive and useful vehicle in certain circumstances. Our plan will continue to keep it in mind.

componenttextpreview: In terms of our need to access the debt capital markets in 2011, we don't necessarily need to do that to take care of everything we need to take care. However, I will point out that the markets appear to be in pretty good shape. And we do have a maturity
componenttext: In terms of our need to access the debt capital markets in 2011, we don't necessarily need to do that to take care of everything we need to take care. However, I will point out that the markets appear to be in pretty good shape. And we do have a maturity in 2012 of around $315 million. So we you look at accessing the debt capital markets opportunistically. And I would say we don't need to access them in 2011 but we want to maintain that option to the extent we like what we're seeing in the markets, we may go ahead and take some of that 2012 maturity off the table.

componenttext: Yes. For 2011, as it stands today, we have about $160 million allocated to NGT&S for growth, primarily Marcellus growth. And we could see that toggling upwards as opportunities materialize. So that would be the area of sensitivity, the area where we think we have upside on the spend.

componenttextpreview: Yes, we think we're firmly within that $1 billion to $1.1 billion window. Let me give you a bit of additional color. Clearly the Indiana commission's approval of the scrubber program in Indiana has tripped a wire for us to begin work on that project. So w
componenttext: Yes, we think we're firmly within that $1 billion to $1.1 billion window. Let me give you a bit of additional color. Clearly the Indiana commission's approval of the scrubber program in Indiana has tripped a wire for us to begin work on that project. So we're going to accelerate some of that spending to ensure that we get that scrubber in place and operational by the end of 2013.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Bob, on the economy, I think one of the last question was talking about 4Q versus 3Q which is interesting rearview stuff. But I'd love your sort of feel of what the economy's suggesting to you sort of right now for the balance of 2011 and particularly in
componenttext: Bob, on the economy, I think one of the last question was talking about 4Q versus 3Q which is interesting rearview stuff. But I'd love your sort of feel of what the economy's suggesting to you sort of right now for the balance of 2011 and particularly in Indiana where you're sitting, but as well as throughout the other territories.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, we just believe it's going to be a slow, gradual recovery of the economy. We certainly observed with interest U.S. Steel's recent announcement about market conditions. You may recall while they have a good strong order book for Q1, they were squarely
componenttext: Yes, we just believe it's going to be a slow, gradual recovery of the economy. We certainly observed with interest U.S. Steel's recent announcement about market conditions. You may recall while they have a good strong order book for Q1, they were squarely in the camp of believing that the economy was going to continue to be slow and the recovery was going to be measured. So obviously, we listened to our big customers pretty carefully and like them, we just believe it's going to be very, very gradual. And that's what the estimate reflects.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: We call this business park and loan optimization, and Columbia Gas Transmission is the primary pipe for the activity. And historically, the business has ranged from $15 million to $20 million annually, to as high as $40 million annually. I alluded to 2009
componenttext: We call this business park and loan optimization, and Columbia Gas Transmission is the primary pipe for the activity. And historically, the business has ranged from $15 million to $20 million annually, to as high as $40 million annually. I alluded to 2009 at NGT&S, we exceeded $40 million in revenue. But this market, this line of business which is relatively small for us at the margin, is solely dependent on gas price volatility and more particularly with seasonality spreads on how we capture the margin on this short-term park and loan activity. So 2009 we're $40 million, 2010 that number dropped to $20 million, again a function of price volatility and going forward, we baked in an forecast more modest level, in or about $20 million is what the forecast reflect.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Renewals, we expect strong renewals this year. We frankly don't have much coming up in 2011. 2012, 2013, we have bigger slug of renewals due. In fact, Columbia Gas has a fairly significant contract position that's due for renewal in 2012, '13. And right n
componenttext: Renewals, we expect strong renewals this year. We frankly don't have much coming up in 2011. 2012, 2013, we have bigger slug of renewals due. In fact, Columbia Gas has a fairly significant contract position that's due for renewal in 2012, '13. And right now, the outlook assumes that we have no significant term back. We have significant reduction in rate levels. And one thing I would point out, when you look at throughput, Columbia Gulf throughput has held up good during 2010. It was down during the first half and recovered quite well. So that's number one. Number two, we've had a couple of recent renewals that again would indicate Columbia Gulf is going to be very competitive. And we feel good about the position of that pipeline.

Those packages are still in discussion phase and have not yet really garnered a lot of air time at the legislature at this point. But we'll continue to work on that.

componenttext: Sure, happy to do that. We're in the process of renewing our facility. And the size of it is going to be maintained at $1.5 billion. We're looking at a four-year renewal. headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. I think we're in good shape at $1.5 billion of liquidity. And I would just point out that we have moved to an auction arrangement for a percentage of the volumes in Ohio. So over the next two to three years, we'll see probably a reduction through liqu
componenttext: No. I think we're in good shape at $1.5 billion of liquidity. And I would just point out that we have moved to an auction arrangement for a percentage of the volumes in Ohio. So over the next two to three years, we'll see probably a reduction through liquidity as we refocus that transition. At this point though, we feel that $1 billion to $1.5 billion is adequate. And we want to maintain it better for the foreseeable future. We don't anticipate needing more liquidity than that.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2010 NiSource Earnings Conference Call. My name is Danielle, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for tod
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2010 NiSource Earnings Conference Call. My name is Danielle, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Mr. Glen Kettering, Senior Vice President of Corporate Affairs. Please proceed.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you and good morning. On behalf of NiSource, I'd like to welcome you to our quarterly analyst call. Joining me this morning are Bob Skaggs, President and Chief Executive Officer; Steve Smith, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and
componenttext:
Thank you and good morning. On behalf of NiSource, I'd like to welcome you to our quarterly analyst call. Joining me this morning are Bob Skaggs, President and Chief Executive Officer; Steve Smith, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Randy Hulen, Managing Director of Investor Relations.
As you know, the focus of today's call is to review our financial performance for the fourth quarter and full year 2010 and to provide a business update. We'll then open the call to your questions. At times during the call, we will refer to the supplemental slides available on our website at nisource.com.
I'd like to remind you that some of the statements made on this conference call will be forward-looking statements. These statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed in the statements. Information concerning such risks and uncertainties is included in the MD&A and Risk Factors sections of our periodic SEC filings.
And now I'll turn the call over to Bob Skaggs.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Glen. Good morning and thanks for joining us. Today, we'll cover several key points before opening the line to your questions. First, I'll address NiSource's strong overall performance for 2010. As you can see, the team once again delivered financ
componenttext:
Thanks, Glen. Good morning and thanks for joining us. Today, we'll cover several key points before opening the line to your questions. First, I'll address NiSource's strong overall performance for 2010. As you can see, the team once again delivered financial results in line with our earnings guidance while taking significant steps towards meeting customer needs, creating shareholder value and generating long-term sustainable earnings growth. 
I'll also touch on the foundational actions taken during 2010 to strengthen NiSource's financial profile and enhance our ability to find a wide array of attractive infrastructure modernization and growth investment opportunities. And finally, I'll outline our 2011 earnings guidance, which reflects our continued commitment to sustainable earnings growth and underscores the underlying strength of NiSource's core businesses and the markets that we serve.
So first, let's turn to our 2010 results. For the year, we continued to see positive customer benefits, enhanced shareholder value and sustainable earnings growth from NiSource's well-established infrastructure investment-driven strategy. During 2010, our team executed on a broad array of key regulatory and financial initiatives, infrastructure enhancement programs and new growth projects. 
These achievements, combined with improved margins and increased usage in our industrial electric markets, enabled us to deliver on our earnings commitments for the fourth consecutive year. For 2010, that means delivering earnings squarely in line with the increased non-GAAP range of $1.20 to $1.25 per share that we provided when we reported earnings for the third quarter. And notably, we achieved these results while remaining responsive to the needs of our customers and other key stakeholders.
On Slide 3 of the supplemental slides, you can see that NiSource delivered 2010 net operating earnings non-GAAP of about $340 million or $1.22 per share compared to $1.07 per share last year, representing a 14% increase over 2009. Our earnings release and supplemental slides spell out the details regarding our improved 2010 results. 
But here are just a few highlights. We saw materially improved industrial margins and usage in our Electric business, which helped boost operating earnings by more than $50 million over 2009. In addition, our Gas Distribution infrastructure enhancement and regulatory initiatives helped generate more than $50 million in added revenues. In our Gas Pipeline and Storage business, the successful completion of growth project helped increase demand margin revenues by more than $20 million over 2009 despite the fact that a number of our projects were in service for only a portion of the year. These results reflect the core strength of our business plan, the focus of our team as well as continued signs of resilience in our key markets.
Going forward, I'm convinced that NiSource's established infrastructure investment-driven strategy will continue to generate positive results for our company, our customers and our investors. We remain committed to this strategy and are focused on executing it in a disciplined, thoughtful manner.
Turning to Slide 4, this slide highlights several key initiatives Steve Smith and our finance team completed during 2010. These efforts significantly strengthened our financial profile and position us to fund our compelling array of infrastructure investment opportunities. 
Most notably in September, we completed a $400 million equity offering. This offering, which was structured as a forward-sale arrangement, aligns with and strongly supports our targeted annual capital investment level, which I'm pleased to note for 2011 is targeted at up to $1.1 billion. In addition, in December, we successfully tendered nearly $275 million in debt and concurrently executed a 30-year debt offering of $250 million. 
This will reduce our interest expense by about $10 million in 2011 and extends the maturity of our debt profile. Of course, we also remain true to our key financial commitments to preserve our stable investment grade credit rating and maintain our attractive secure dividend, all while delivering long-term earnings growth.
With the successful completion of our equity offering and other key elements of financial strategy, NiSource is well-positioned to take advantage of the deep inventory of investment opportunities available across our Business portfolio and continue growing our business and earnings on a sustainable basis.
Before turning to our 2011 outlook, let me touch on just some of the key business unit accomplishments that play such key role in advancing our business strategy. 
First and foremost, we continue to see solid progress in Indiana. Jimmy Staton and his NIPSCO team are taking significant steps to improve customer service and reliability while addressing a number of important regulatory matters. In November, NIPSCO filed a new electric rate case with the Indiana Utility Regulatory Commission or IURC. 
While filed in November, the preparation and stakeholder outreach and engagement for the case began long before that. The result is a proposal that is balanced and responsive to both the needs of the company and our customers and other constituencies. We'll continue to engage with all stakeholders and expect the case to be completed during 2011. As we mentioned in today's release and have discussed in past updates, we expect to restore NIPSCO's earnings to a reasonable and appropriate level by the beginning of 2012.
Also in November, NIPSCO received IURC approval of the unanimous settlement of its 2010 natural gas rate case, the company's first in 20 years. The settlement resulted in an overall rate decrease for customers while enhancing the company's operating earnings. It also improved rate design and continued our strong support for low-income assistance, energy efficiency and conservation.
Last, but not least, following IURC certificate approval at the end of December, NIPSCO is launching a major environmental upgrade at our Schahfer Generating Station, which will contribute to the company's earnings growth going forward. This is the first phase of a series of new environmental investments in Indiana, totaling about $600 million over the next six to eight years. These initiatives are fully in line with NIPSCO's new source review settlement with the EPA that we announced earlier this year.
Turning to our NiSource Gas Transmission & Storage business on Slide 7. Chris Helms and his team are continuing to capitalize on NiSource's unparalleled geographic footprint to complete and advance customer-driven growth projects primarily in the Marcellus Shale production area. During 2010, NGT&S put in service or nearly completed more than $150 million in strategic growth projects serving the Marcellus Shale production area. These products provide market access for more than 500,000 dekatherms of natural gas daily. 
Our $80 million Majorsville series of projects serve as the cornerstone of an array of additional projects currently in process across the Marcellus play. Progress also continued on our Columbia Gulf Transmission rate case for the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. The following seeks an increase in revenues of approximately $50 million per year, reflecting updated costs and operating conditions. New rates go into effect subject to refund starting this May.
As I noted earlier, growth project revenues were up by more than $20 million in NGT&S in 2010, and for projects such as Majorsville, we've not yet experienced a full year's earnings run rate. Having said that, overall operating earnings for the year were down due to anticipated expense increases, pension and integrity management in particular and reduced short-term transportation revenue resulting from a lack of natural gas price volatility. Looking forward, we remain enthusiastic about NGT&S' earnings growth prospects for 2011 and beyond, driven by accretive infrastructure investments, which we expect to amount to about $200 million annually.
Turning to our third major business unit, NiSource Gas Distribution or NGD. Our NGD teams continued to execute on our strategy of combining long-term infrastructure replacement programs with complementary regulatory initiatives. 
Millions of customers are benefiting from this strategy, which includes significant revenue-producing facility modernization programs at our largest utilities, Columbia Gas of Ohio, Columbia Gas of Pennsylvania and Columbia Gas of Massachusetts. In aggregate, these programs provide NGD with an investment opportunity approaching $4.5 billion over the next 20 to 25 years. 
On the regulatory front in December, Columbia Gas of Virginia received approval from the Virginia State Corporation Commission of a unanimous settlement of its first base rate case in 12 years.  The settlement authorized a $5 million revenue increase as well as a number of rate design and other enhancements. The new rates took effect January 1. 
And in mid-January, Columbia Gas of Pennsylvania filed a new rate case with the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission. That case seeks recovery of ongoing infrastructure investments, a modernized rate structure, as well as new senior citizen and energy efficiency programs. The filing seeks an annual revenue increase of about $38 million.
Finally, I'd like to briefly outline our 2011 earnings guidance and key 2010 takeaways on Slide 8 before opening the line to your questions. Based on the continued success of our balanced business strategy and the extensive array of growth investment opportunities available across all of our businesses, we remain confident that NiSource will sustainably grow long-term earnings in the range of 3% to 5% annually.
In fact, in the near term, particularly as we execute a number of regulatory initiatives, our operating earnings growth may well exceed that longer-term percentage range. 
With that in mind, we expect NiSource's 2011 net operating earnings to fall within a range of $1.25 to $1.35 per share. You should know, this is a non-GAAP range. Consistent with last year's outlook due to the unpredictability of weather and other factors, we're not providing GAAP earnings guidance. I'll also note that our 2011 guidance continues to be premised on a relatively modest and gradual economic recovery across the markets we serve.
In closing, I'd like to acknowledge our team, our customers and our many business community partners for their support and engagement during the past year. We've made significant progress on our business plan during 2010, all built on a foundation of ongoing investment across all of our companies.  
This core strategy remains unchanged for 2011, with the notable enhancement of our ability to invest in our businesses by the steps taken over the last years. And I can assure you that our investment approach will remain disciplined and straightforward, focused on meeting our customer needs while building long-term value for our shareholders.
As always, we remain committed to communicating with our stakeholders in a transparent and timely manner regarding these and all of our efforts. Ongoing updates will be provided through our analyst calls and news releases posted on NiSource.com. 
Thank you for participating today and for your continued interest and support of NiSource. Now Danielle, let's open the call to questions.

componenttextpreview: Bob, could you help give me some color with respect to where we are in the Indiana settlement with respect to -- if we're looking at, I guess, new rates perhaps being effective beginning of 2012, since the IURC is going to need to approve that, does that
componenttext: Bob, could you help give me some color with respect to where we are in the Indiana settlement with respect to -- if we're looking at, I guess, new rates perhaps being effective beginning of 2012, since the IURC is going to need to approve that, does that suggest a settlement basically midyear, is that kind of the effective timing?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just the one key point on context for this case, we filed rate case two under the commission's expedited rules processing guidelines. And the commission accepted that filing under those guidelines and, in fact, has established an expedited procedural sche
componenttext: Just the one key point on context for this case, we filed rate case two under the commission's expedited rules processing guidelines. And the commission accepted that filing under those guidelines and, in fact, has established an expedited procedural schedule for the case, Paul, that would provide for a decision during the fourth quarter of 2011. So if this case is litigated, it would proceed along that schedule, and we feel confident the commission would render a decision during the fourth quarter, which would enable us to put rates into effect at the beginning of 2012. Now again, that context, our intent, our hope, our desire would be to try to settle this case. And as I've mentioned consistently, we put full core press during the first quarter into the second quarter to attempt to settle this before the other parties have to put there witnesses on the stand and subject them to cross examinations. So we're now on a window, we're engaged in the parties, and we're going to work diligently to try to settle this prior to midyear.

componenttext: More holistically in the sense that cost allocation is an issue that remains. And we've attempted in rate case to set a direction that would provide the parties an opportunity to compromise on cost allocation. But we believe that will continue to be the key challenge in resolving this case sooner rather than later. Just let me add, Carl, that we continue to believe that the traditional cost of service rate base sorts of issues are straightforward.

componenttext: And then one last question if I could, so lots of moving parts as there always are, as we look to 2011 guidance and we look to segment, clearly LDC should be doing well given some of the depreciation changes that have happened at NIPSCO gas. componenttext: We expect all three units to perform well. NGT&S in particular, we expect a strong year. So again, all three units, Carl, ought to be performing quite well in 2011. That's the expectation.

componenttext: We believe the core reliability and integrity management spends will be, give or take, flat year-to-year. componenttext: Thanks, Bob. The accelerated depreciation resulted from the legislation passed here recently. Over the next couple of years, 2011, 2012, it's going to provide between $300 million and $400 million of benefit over the next several years, so it is a timing mechanism. You'll recall that in 2011, we get 100% bonus depreciation and in 2012, we get 50% bonus depreciation. So we've taken a rough estimate at what we believe bonus depreciation will provide to us in 2011. And that's in between $150 million and $200 million. And that is reflected in the sources and uses statement for 2011.

componenttext: Jay, in terms of our need to access the debt capital markets in 2011, we don't necessarily need to do that to take care of everything we need to take care. However, I will point out that the markets appear to be in pretty good shape. And we do have a maturity in 2012 of around $315 million. So we you look at accessing the debt capital markets opportunistically. And I would say we don't need to access them in 2011, but we want to maintain that option to the extent we like what we're seeing in the markets, we may go ahead and take some of that 2012 maturity off the table.

componenttext: Lastly, Bob, on the economy, I think one of the last question was talking about 4Q versus 3Q, which is interesting rearview mirror stuff. headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, we just believe it's going to be a slow, gradual recovery of the economy. We certainly observed with interest U.S. Steel's recent announcement about market conditions. You may recall, they said while they have a good strong order book for Q1, they we
componenttext: Yes, we just believe it's going to be a slow, gradual recovery of the economy. We certainly observed with interest U.S. Steel's recent announcement about market conditions. You may recall, they said while they have a good strong order book for Q1, they were squarely in the camp of believing that the economy was going to continue to be slow and the recovery was going to be measured. So, obviously, we listened to our big customers pretty carefully and like them, we just believe it's going to be very, very gradual. And that's what the estimate reflects.

componenttext: Yes, our sense on steel productions in our areas is about 70% utilization, maybe a little bit north of that number. Again, U.S. Steel indicates that they have a pretty good order book for Q1 and then it's pretty slow after that. So decent utilization rates in our area.

componenttext: And is there any way to think about how that might impact if we get back up towards the 80%, 90%, how that might impact the earnings in NIPSCO?

componenttext: Well, again, the key going forward is resolution of this new NIPSCO rate case. I mentioned cost allocation rate design, the impact of load growth will be determined by how those rates are designed.

componenttext: And then just switching gears onto the pipes. headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: We call this business park and loan optimization, and Columbia Gas Transmission is the primary pipe for that activity. And historically, the business has ranged from $15 million to $20 million annually, to as high as $40 million annually. And I alluded to
componenttext: We call this business park and loan optimization, and Columbia Gas Transmission is the primary pipe for that activity. And historically, the business has ranged from $15 million to $20 million annually, to as high as $40 million annually. And I alluded to 2009, at NGT&S, we exceeded $40 million in revenue. But this market, this line of business, which is relatively small for us at the margin, is solely dependent on gas price volatility and more particularly with seasonal spreads or that's how we capture the margin on this short-term park and loan activity. So 2009, we're at $40 million. 2010, that number dropped to $20 million, again, a function of price volatility. And going forward, we baked in to the forecast a more modest level, in or about $20 million is what the forecast reflects.

componenttext: I wanted to follow up on the CapEx for 2011 and going forward. componenttext: No, we still believe it's $1 billion is a representative number. But as you said, better than I did, that it could tick up, it could tick down depending on conditions. And one of the key sensitivities is can we deploy the way we believe we can deploy in the Marcellus region.

componenttext: And then switching gears to -- could you talk a little bit about in the Gas Transmission, specifically on Columbia Gulf? Can you remind us what percent of contacts come up for renewal in 2011 and kind of what you baked into your outlook regarding just renewal rates?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: On renewals, we expect to have strong renewals this year. We frankly don't have much coming up in 2011. 2012, 2013, we have a bigger slug of renewals due. In fact, Columbia Gas of Ohio has a fairly significant contract position that's due for renewal in 2
componenttext: On renewals, we expect to have strong renewals this year. We frankly don't have much coming up in 2011. 2012, 2013, we have a bigger slug of renewals due. In fact, Columbia Gas of Ohio has a fairly significant contract position that's due for renewal in 2012, '13. And right now, the outlook assumes that we have no significant term back. We have no significant reduction in rate levels. One thing I would point out when you look at throughput, Columbia Gulf throughput has held up good during 2010. It was down during the first half and recovered quite well. So that's number one. Number two, we've had a couple of recent renewals that again would indicate that Columbia Gulf is going to be very competitive, and we feel good about the position of that pipeline.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's an active session in the legislature. You may recall that current governor, Mitch Daniels, filed two years of office. This election cycle gave him not only a Republican Senate but a Republican House. So he has an aggressive agenda lined up to complet
componenttext: It's an active session in the legislature. You may recall that current governor, Mitch Daniels, filed two years of office. This election cycle gave him not only a Republican Senate but a Republican House. So he has an aggressive agenda lined up to complete his term as Governor. We and other utilities have been discussing legislative proposals that would help, we believe, streamline and modernize IURC regulation. Those packages are still in discussion phase and have not yet really garnered a lot of air time at the legislature at this point. But we'll continue to work on that.

componenttext: Yes, you do. One thing again though I just want to highlight, in 2012, 2013, we have one significant in Greenwood Columbia Gas of Ohio that needs to be dealt with. And again, we believe Columbia Gulf is in great position.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: We're in the process of renewing our facility. And the size of it is going to be maintained at $1.5 billion. We're looking at a four-year renewal. You'll also be aware that the facility actually expires in July of 2011 so we are getting ahead of the curve
componenttext: We're in the process of renewing our facility. And the size of it is going to be maintained at $1.5 billion. We're looking at a four-year renewal. You'll also be aware that the facility actually expires in July of 2011 so we are getting ahead of the curve here and anticipate that we'll have that new facility closed within the first quarter. Pricing has gone up. The old facility was in LIBOR plus 50 to 60 basis point range. The new facility is in the LIBOR plus 200 basis point range.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, let me ask a question about the size of the revolver. I mean I understand the working capital needs that you have. But I mean right now your -- liquidity available is right around $400 million. Gas is relatively low at the current time. From a worki
componenttext: Well, let me ask a question about the size of the revolver. I mean I understand the working capital needs that you have. But I mean right now your -- liquidity available is right around $400 million. Gas is relatively low at the current time. From a working capital standpoint and given your credit rating and the amount of debt that you had and the issues that took place back in 2009, anything driven, any thought to increasing the size of the revolver?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. I think we're in good shape at $1.5 billion of liquidity. And I would just point out that we have moved to an auction arrangement for a percentage of the volumes in Ohio. And so over the next two to three years, we'll see probably a reduction through
componenttext: No. I think we're in good shape at $1.5 billion of liquidity. And I would just point out that we have moved to an auction arrangement for a percentage of the volumes in Ohio. And so over the next two to three years, we'll see probably a reduction through liquidity as we result of that transition. At this point though, we feel that $1 billion to $1.5 billion is adequate, and we want to maintain it there for the foreseeable future. We don't anticipate needing more liquidity than that.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2010 NiSource Earnings Conference Call. My name is Danielle, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for tod
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2010 NiSource Earnings Conference Call. My name is Danielle, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Mr. Glen Kettering, Senior Vice President of Corporate Affairs. Please proceed.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you and good morning. On behalf of NiSource, I'd like to welcome you to our quarterly analyst call. Joining me this morning are Bob Skaggs, President and Chief Executive Officer; Steve Smith, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and
componenttext:
Thank you and good morning. On behalf of NiSource, I'd like to welcome you to our quarterly analyst call. Joining me this morning are Bob Skaggs, President and Chief Executive Officer; Steve Smith, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Randy Hulen, Managing Director of Investor Relations.
As you know, the focus of today's call is to review our financial performance for the fourth quarter and full year 2010 and to provide a business update. We'll then open the call to your questions. At times during the call, we will refer to the supplemental slides available on our website at nisource.com.
I'd like to remind you that some of the statements made on this conference call will be forward-looking statements. These statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed in the statements. Information concerning such risks and uncertainties is included in the MD&A and Risk Factors sections of our periodic SEC filings.
And now I'll turn the call over to Bob Skaggs.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Glen. Good morning and thanks for joining us. Today, we'll cover several key points before opening the line to your questions. First, I'll address NiSource's strong overall performance for 2010. As you can see, the team once again delivered financ
componenttext:
Thanks, Glen. Good morning and thanks for joining us. Today, we'll cover several key points before opening the line to your questions. First, I'll address NiSource's strong overall performance for 2010. As you can see, the team once again delivered financial results in line with our earnings guidance while taking significant steps towards meeting customer needs, creating shareholder value and generating long-term sustainable earnings growth. 
I'll also touch on the foundational actions taken during 2010 to strengthen NiSource's financial profile and enhance our ability to fund a wide array of attractive infrastructure modernization and growth investment opportunities. And finally, I'll outline our 2011 earnings guidance, which reflects our continued commitment to sustainable earnings growth and underscores the underlying strength of NiSource's core businesses and the markets that we serve.
So first, let's turn to our 2010 results. For the year, we continued to see positive customer benefits, enhanced shareholder value and sustainable earnings growth from NiSource's well-established infrastructure investment-driven strategy. During 2010, our team executed on a broad array of key regulatory and financial initiatives, infrastructure enhancement programs and new growth projects. 
These achievements, combined with improved margins and increased usage in our industrial electric markets, enabled us to deliver on our earnings commitments for the fourth consecutive year. For 2010, that means delivering earnings squarely in line with the increased non-GAAP range of $1.20 to $1.25 per share that we provided when we reported earnings for the third quarter. And notably, we achieved these results while remaining responsive to the needs of our customers and other key stakeholders.
On Slide 3 of the supplemental slides, you can see that NiSource delivered 2010 net operating earnings non-GAAP of about $340 million or $1.22 per share compared to $1.07 per share last year, representing a 14% increase over 2009. Our earnings release and supplemental slides spell out the details regarding our improved 2010 results. 
But here are just a few highlights. We saw materially improved industrial margins and usage in our Electric business, which helped boost operating earnings by more than $50 million over 2009. In addition, our Gas Distribution infrastructure enhancement and regulatory initiatives helped generate more than $50 million in added revenues. In our Gas Pipeline and Storage business, the successful completion of growth project helped increase demand margin revenues by more than $20 million over 2009 despite the fact that a number of our projects were in service for only a portion of the year. These results reflect the core strength of our business plan, the focus of our team as well as continued signs of resilience in our key markets.
Going forward, I'm convinced that NiSource's established infrastructure investment-driven strategy will continue to generate positive results for our company, our customers and our investors. We remain committed to this strategy and are focused on executing it in a disciplined, thoughtful manner.
Turning to Slide 4, this slide highlights several key initiatives Steve Smith and our finance team completed during 2010. These efforts significantly strengthened our financial profile and position us to fund our compelling array of infrastructure investment opportunities. 
Most notably in September, we completed a $400 million equity offering. This offering, which was structured as a forward-sale arrangement, aligns with and strongly supports our targeted annual capital investment level, which I'm pleased to note for 2011 is targeted at up to $1.1 billion. In addition, in December, we successfully tendered nearly $275 million in debt and concurrently executed a 30-year debt offering of $250 million. 
This will reduce our interest expense by about $10 million in 2011 and extends the maturity of our debt profile. Of course, we also remain true to our key financial commitments to preserve our stable investment grade credit rating and maintain our attractive secure dividend, all while delivering long-term earnings growth.
With the successful completion of our equity offering and other key elements of financial strategy, NiSource is well-positioned to take advantage of the deep inventory of investment opportunities available across our Business portfolio and continue growing our business and earnings on a sustainable basis.
Before turning to our 2011 outlook, let me touch on just some of the key business unit accomplishments that play such key role in advancing our business strategy. 
First and foremost, we continue to see solid progress in Indiana. Jimmy Staton and his NIPSCO team are taking significant steps to improve customer service and reliability while addressing a number of important regulatory matters. In November, NIPSCO filed a new electric rate case with the Indiana Utility Regulatory Commission or IURC. 
While filed in November, the preparation and stakeholder outreach and engagement for the case began long before that. The result is a proposal that is balanced and responsive to both the needs of the company and our customers and other constituencies. We'll continue to engage with all stakeholders and expect the case to be completed during 2011. As we mentioned in today's release and have discussed in past updates, we expect to restore NIPSCO's earnings to a reasonable and appropriate level by the beginning of 2012.
Also in November, NIPSCO received IURC approval of the unanimous settlement of its 2010 natural gas rate case, the company's first in 20 years. The settlement resulted in an overall rate decrease for customers while enhancing the company's operating earnings. It also improved rate design and continued our strong support for low-income assistance, energy efficiency and conservation.
Last, but not least, following IURC certificate approval at the end of December, NIPSCO is launching a major environmental upgrade at our Schahfer Generating Station, which will contribute to the company's earnings growth going forward. This is the first phase of a series of new environmental investments in Indiana, totaling about $600 million over the next six to eight years. These initiatives are fully in line with NIPSCO's new source review settlement with the EPA that we announced earlier this year.
Turning to our NiSource Gas Transmission & Storage business on Slide 7. Chris Helms and his team are continuing to capitalize on NiSource's unparalleled geographic footprint to complete and advance customer-driven growth projects primarily in the Marcellus Shale production area. During 2010, NGT&S put in service or nearly completed more than $150 million in strategic growth projects serving the Marcellus Shale production area. These products provide market access for more than 500,000 dekatherms of natural gas daily. 
Our $80 million Majorsville series of projects serve as the cornerstone of an array of additional projects currently in process across the Marcellus play. Progress also continued on our Columbia Gulf Transmission rate case for the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. The following seeks an increase in revenues of approximately $50 million per year, reflecting updated costs and operating conditions. New rates go into effect subject to refund starting this May.
As I noted earlier, growth project revenues were up by more than $20 million in NGT&S in 2010, and for projects such as Majorsville, we've not yet experienced a full year's earnings run rate. Having said that, overall operating earnings for the year were down due to anticipated expense increases, pension and integrity management in particular and reduced short-term transportation revenue resulting from a lack of natural gas price volatility. Looking forward, we remain enthusiastic about NGT&S' earnings growth prospects for 2011 and beyond, driven by accretive infrastructure investments, which we expect to amount to about $200 million annually.
Turning to our third major business unit, NiSource Gas Distribution or NGD. Our NGD teams continued to execute on our strategy of combining long-term infrastructure replacement programs with complementary regulatory initiatives. 
Millions of customers are benefiting from this strategy, which includes significant revenue-producing facility modernization programs at our largest utilities, Columbia Gas of Ohio, Columbia Gas of Pennsylvania and Columbia Gas of Massachusetts. In aggregate, these programs provide NGD with an investment opportunity approaching $4.5 billion over the next 20 to 25 years. 
On the regulatory front in December, Columbia Gas of Virginia received approval from the Virginia State Corporation Commission of a unanimous settlement of its first base rate case in 12 years.  The settlement authorized a $5 million revenue increase as well as a number of rate design and other enhancements. The new rates took effect January 1st. 
And in mid-January, Columbia Gas of Pennsylvania filed a new rate case with the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission. That case seeks recovery of ongoing infrastructure investments, a modernized rate structure, as well as new senior citizen and energy efficiency programs. The filing seeks an annual revenue increase of about $38 million.
Finally, I'd like to briefly outline our 2011 earnings guidance and key 2010 takeaways on Slide 8 before opening the line to your questions. Based on the continued success of our balanced business strategy and the extensive array of growth investment opportunities available across all of our businesses, we remain confident that NiSource will sustainably grow long-term earnings in the range of 3% to 5% annually.
In fact, in the near term, particularly as we execute a number of regulatory initiatives, our operating earnings growth may well exceed that longer-term percentage range. 
With that in mind, we expect NiSource's 2011 net operating earnings to fall within a range of $1.25 to $1.35 per share. You should know, this is a non-GAAP range. Consistent with last year's outlook due to the unpredictability of weather and other factors, we're not providing GAAP earnings guidance. I'll also note that our 2011 guidance continues to be premised on a relatively modest and gradual economic recovery across the markets we serve.
In closing, I'd like to acknowledge our team, our customers and our many business community partners for their support and engagement during the past year. We've made significant progress on our business plan during 2010, all built on a foundation of ongoing investment across all of our companies.  
This core strategy remains unchanged for 2011, with the notable enhancement of our ability to invest in our businesses by the steps taken over the last years. And I can assure you that our investment approach will remain disciplined and straightforward, focused on meeting our customer needs while building long-term value for our shareholders.
As always, we remain committed to communicating with our stakeholders in a transparent and timely manner regarding these and all of our efforts. Ongoing updates will be provided through our analyst calls and news releases posted on NiSource.com. 
Thank you for participating today and for your continued interest and support of NiSource. Now Danielle, let's open the call to questions.

componenttextpreview: Bob, could you help give me some color with respect to where we are in the Indiana settlement with respect to? If we're looking at, I guess, new rates perhaps being effective beginning of 2012, since the IURC is going to need to approve that, does that su
componenttext: Bob, could you help give me some color with respect to where we are in the Indiana settlement with respect to? If we're looking at, I guess, new rates perhaps being effective beginning of 2012, since the IURC is going to need to approve that, does that suggest a settlement basically midyear, is that kind of the effective timing?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just the one key point on context for this case, we filed rate case two under the commission's expedited rules processing guidelines. And the commission accepted that filing under those guidelines and, in fact, has established an expedited procedural sche
componenttext: Just the one key point on context for this case, we filed rate case two under the commission's expedited rules processing guidelines. And the commission accepted that filing under those guidelines and, in fact, has established an expedited procedural schedule for the case, Paul, that would provide for a decision during the fourth quarter of 2011. So if this case is litigated, it would proceed along that schedule, and we feel confident the commission would render a decision during the fourth quarter, which would enable us to put rates into effect at the beginning of 2012. Now again, that context, our intent, our hope, our desire would be to try to settle this case. And as I've mentioned consistently, we put full court press during the first quarter into the second quarter to attempt to settle this before the other parties have to put there witnesses on the stand and subject them to cross examinations. So we're now on a window, we're engaged in the parties, and we're going to work diligently to try to settle this prior to midyear.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Bob, one other kind of question off of that. In the 2010 rate case, was all about this sort of conservation and pension and, of course, the host of more thorny issues for the 2008 case. The motion to vacate and sort of settlement discussions as it's ongoi
componenttext: Bob, one other kind of question off of that. In the 2010 rate case, was all about this sort of conservation and pension and, of course, the host of more thorny issues for the 2008 case. The motion to vacate and sort of settlement discussions as it's ongoing right now, are most of the conversations with shippers on the 2010 issues or is it still sort of looking at it more holistically, shall we say?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011

componenttext: More holistically in the sense that cost allocation is an issue that remains. And we've attempted in rate case to set a direction that would provide the parties an opportunity to compromise on cost allocation. But we believe that will continue to be the key challenge in resolving this case sooner rather than later. Just let me add, Carl, that we continue to believe that the traditional cost of service rate base sorts of issues are straight forward.

componenttext: And then one last question if I could, so lots of moving parts as there always are, as we look to 2011 guidance and we look to segment, clearly LDC should be doing well given some of the depreciation changes that have happened at NIPSCO gas. As we're kind of looking at the pluses and minuses that are happening, like what happened to transportation, even though we have some good demand charge addition, the O&M kind of overwhelmed at least for a little while, should we still be expecting a possible slide on a net basis in pipelines for 2011 before perhaps kicking up in 2012? I just want to be sort of on the look out of if there's any particular unit that might, in fact, be sliding on an operating income basis.

componenttext: We expect all three units to perform well. NGT&S in particular, we expect a strong year. We have baked into the estimate of relatively conservative outlook on our optimization, short-term Transportation business at NGT&S. So we believe that, that hit is behind us. So again, all three units, Carl, ought to be performing quite well in 2011. That's the expectation.

componenttext: We believe the core reliability and integrity management spends will be, give or take, flat year-to-year. We think some of the headwinds we had with pension expense at NGT&S, and you will recall that they're on a cash basis, they're not on a expense basis and that's because of FERC treatment of pension and their rate. So again, we believe that, that will flatten out as well.

componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. The accelerated depreciation resulted from the legislation passed here recently. Over the next couple of years, 2011, 2012, it's going to provide between $300 million and $400 million of benefit over the next several years, so it is a timing
componenttext: Thanks, Bob. The accelerated depreciation resulted from the legislation passed here recently. Over the next couple of years, 2011, 2012, it's going to provide between $300 million and $400 million of benefit over the next several years, so it is a timing mechanism. You'll recall that in 2011, we get 100% bonus depreciation and in 2012, we get 50% bonus depreciation. So we've taken a rough estimate at what we believe bonus depreciation will provide to us in 2011. And that's in between $150 million and $200 million. And that is reflected in the sources and uses statement for 2011.

So as our plan unfolds, we'll continue to keep it in mind.

componenttext: Jay, in terms of our need to access the debt capital markets in 2011, we don't necessarily need to do that to take care of everything we need to take care. However, I will point out that the markets appear to be in pretty good shape. And we do have a maturity in 2012 of around $315 million. So we you look at accessing the debt capital markets opportunistically. And I would say we don't need to access them in 2011, but we want to maintain that option to the extent we like what we're seeing in the markets, we may go ahead and take some of that 2012 maturity off the table.

componenttext: Yes, we think we're firmly within that $1 billion to $1.1 billion window. And let me, Jay, just give you a bit of additional color. Clearly, the Indiana commission's approval of the scrubber program in Indiana has tripped a wire for us to begin work on that project. So we're going to accelerate some of that spending to ensure that we get that scrubber place and operational by the end of 2013.

componenttextpreview: Lastly, Bob, on the economy, I think one of the last question was talking about 4Q versus 3Q, which is interesting rearview mirror stuff. But I'd love your sort of feel of what the economy's suggesting to you sort of right now for the balance of 2011, in
componenttext: Lastly, Bob, on the economy, I think one of the last question was talking about 4Q versus 3Q, which is interesting rearview mirror stuff. But I'd love your sort of feel of what the economy's suggesting to you sort of right now for the balance of 2011, in particularly in Indiana where you're sitting, but as well throughout the other territories.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, we just believe it's going to be a slow, gradual recovery of the economy. We certainly observed with interest U.S. Steel's recent announcement about market conditions. You may recall, they said while they have a good strong order book for Q1, they we
componenttext: Yes, we just believe it's going to be a slow, gradual recovery of the economy. We certainly observed with interest U.S. Steel's recent announcement about market conditions. You may recall, they said while they have a good strong order book for Q1, they were squarely in the camp of believing that the economy was going to continue to be slow and the recovery was going to be measured. So, obviously, we listened to our big customers pretty carefully and like them, we just believe it's going to be very, very gradual. And that's what the estimate reflects.

componenttext: Yes, Ohio and PA, certainly, we see those same sorts of conditions.

componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Jonathan Lefebvre with Wells Fargo.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to touch on the load up tick in the economic recovery that you were just mentioning. And just wondering if maybe you can give us a sense for kind of? I know you have a lot of sensitivity in obviously, the steel industry. Do you have any sens
componenttext: I just wanted to touch on the load up tick in the economic recovery that you were just mentioning. And just wondering if maybe you can give us a sense for kind of? I know you have a lot of sensitivity in obviously, the steel industry. Do you have any sense for the operating rates or utilization rates that they're running at right now? And how much further upside could we see? I'm just trying to help frame that up a bit.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, our sense on steel productions in our areas is about 70% utilization, maybe a little bit north of that number. Again, U.S. Steel indicates that they have a pretty good order book for Q1 and then it's pretty slow after that. So decent utilization rate
componenttext: Yes, our sense on steel productions in our areas is about 70% utilization, maybe a little bit north of that number. Again, U.S. Steel indicates that they have a pretty good order book for Q1 and then it's pretty slow after that. So decent utilization rates in our area.

componenttext: And where are they averaged historically?
