headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2010 NiSource Earnings Conference Call. My name is Danielle, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for tod
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2010 NiSource Earnings Conference Call. My name is Danielle, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Mr. Glen Kettering, Senior Vice President of Corporate Affairs. Please proceed.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you and good morning. On behalf of NiSource, I'd like to welcome you to our quarterly analyst call. Joining me this morning are Bob Skaggs, President and Chief Executive Officer; Steve Smith, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and
componenttext:
Thank you and good morning. On behalf of NiSource, I'd like to welcome you to our quarterly analyst call. Joining me this morning are Bob Skaggs, President and Chief Executive Officer; Steve Smith, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Randy Hulen, Managing Director of Investor Relations.
As you know, the focus of today's call is to review our financial performance for the fourth quarter and full year 2010 and to provide a business update. We'll then open the call to your questions. At times during the call, we will refer to the supplemental slides available on our website at nisource.com.
I'd like to remind you that some of the statements made on this conference call will be forward-looking statements. These statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed in the statements. Information concerning such risks and uncertainties is included in the MD&A and Risk Factors sections of our periodic SEC filings.
And now I'll turn the call over to Bob Skaggs.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Glen. Good morning and thanks for joining us. Today, we'll cover several key points before opening the line to your questions. First, I'll address NiSource's strong overall performance for 2010. As you can see, the team once again delivered financ
componenttext:
Thanks, Glen. Good morning and thanks for joining us. Today, we'll cover several key points before opening the line to your questions. First, I'll address NiSource's strong overall performance for 2010. As you can see, the team once again delivered financial results in line with our earnings guidance while taking significant steps towards meeting customer needs, creating shareholder value and generating long-term sustainable earnings growth. 
I'll also touch on the foundational actions taken during 2010 to strengthen NiSource's financial profile and enhance our ability to fund a wide array of attractive infrastructure modernization and growth investment opportunities. And finally, I'll outline our 2011 earnings guidance, which reflects our continued commitment to sustainable earnings growth and underscores the underlying strength of NiSource's core businesses and the markets that we serve.
So first, let's turn to our 2010 results. For the year, we continued to see positive customer benefits, enhanced shareholder value and sustainable earnings growth from NiSource's well-established infrastructure investment-driven strategy. During 2010, our team executed on a broad array of key regulatory and financial initiatives, infrastructure enhancement programs and new growth projects. 
These achievements, combined with improved margins and increased usage in our industrial electric markets, enabled us to deliver on our earnings commitments for the fourth consecutive year. For 2010, that means delivering earnings squarely in line with the increased non-GAAP range of $1.20 to $1.25 per share that we provided when we reported earnings for the third quarter. And notably, we achieved these results while remaining responsive to the needs of our customers and other key stakeholders.
On Slide 3 of the supplemental slides, you can see that NiSource delivered 2010 net operating earnings non-GAAP of about $340 million or $1.22 per share compared to $1.07 per share last year, representing a 14% increase over 2009. Our earnings release and supplemental slides spell out the details regarding our improved 2010 results. 
But here are just a few highlights. We saw materially improved industrial margins and usage in our Electric business, which helped boost operating earnings by more than $50 million over 2009. In addition, our Gas Distribution infrastructure enhancement and regulatory initiatives helped generate more than $50 million in added revenues. And in our Gas Pipeline and Storage business, the successful completion of growth projects helped increase demand margin revenues by more than $20 million over 2009 despite the fact that a number of our projects were in service for only a portion of the year. These results reflect the core strength of our business plan, the focus of our team as well as continued signs of resilience in our key markets.
Going forward, I'm convinced that NiSource's established infrastructure investment-driven strategy will continue to generate positive results for our company, our customers and our investors. We remain committed to this strategy and are focused on executing it in a disciplined, thoughtful manner.
Turning to Slide 4, this slide highlights several key initiatives Steve Smith and our finance team completed during 2010. These efforts significantly strengthened our financial profile and position us to fund our compelling array of infrastructure investment opportunities. 
Most notably in September, we completed a $400 million equity offering. This offering, which was structured as a forward-sale arrangement, aligns with and strongly supports our targeted annual capital investment level, which I'm pleased to note for 2011 is targeted at up to $1.1 billion. In addition, in December, we successfully tendered nearly $275 million in debt and concurrently executed a 30-year debt offering of $250 million. 
This will reduce our interest expense by about $10 million in 2011 and extends the maturity of our debt profile. Of course, we also remain true to our key financial commitments: to preserve our stable investment-grade credit rating and maintain our attractive secure dividend, all while delivering long-term earnings growth.
With the successful completion of our equity offering and other key elements of financial strategy, NiSource is well-positioned to take advantage of the deep inventory of investment opportunities available across our Business portfolio and continue growing our business and earnings on a sustainable basis.
Before turning to our 2011 outlook, let me touch on just some of the key business unit accomplishments that played such a key role in advancing our business strategy. 
First and foremost, we continue to see solid progress in Indiana. Jimmy Staton and his NIPSCO team are taking significant steps to improve customer service and reliability while addressing a number of important regulatory matters. In November, NIPSCO filed a new electric rate case with the Indiana Utility Regulatory Commission or IURC. 
While filed in November, the preparation and stakeholder outreach and engagement for the case began long before that. The result is a proposal that is balanced and responsive to both the needs of the company and our customers and other constituencies. We'll continue to engage with all stakeholders and expect the case to be completed during 2011. As we mentioned in today's release and have discussed in past updates, we expect to restore NIPSCO's earnings to a reasonable and appropriate level by the beginning of 2012.
Also in November, NIPSCO received IURC approval of the unanimous settlement of its 2010 natural gas rate case, the company's first in 20 years. The settlement resulted in an overall rate decrease for customers while enhancing the company's operating earnings. It also improved rate design and continued our strong support for low-income assistance, energy efficiency and conservation.
Last, but not least, following IURC certificate approval at the end of December, NIPSCO is launching a major environmental upgrade at our Schahfer Generating Station, which will contribute to the company's earnings growth going forward. This is the first phase of a series of new environmental investments in Indiana, totaling about $600 million over the next six to eight years. These initiatives are fully in line with NIPSCO's new source review settlement with the EPA that we announced earlier this year.
Turning to our NiSource Gas Transmission & Storage business on Slide 7. Chris Helms and his team are continuing to capitalize on NiSource's unparalleled geographic footprint to complete and advance customer-driven growth projects primarily in the Marcellus Shale production area. During 2010, NGT&S put in service or nearly completed more than $150 million in strategic growth projects serving the Marcellus Shale production area. These projects provide market access for more than 500,000 dekatherms of natural gas daily. 
Our $80 million Majorsville series of projects serve as the cornerstone of an array of additional projects currently in process across the Marcellus play. Progress also continued on our Columbia Gulf Transmission rate case for the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. The filing seeks an increase in revenues of approximately $50 million per year, reflecting updated costs and operating conditions. New rates go into effect subject to refund starting this May.
As I noted earlier, growth project revenues were up by more than $20 million at NGT&S in 2010, and for projects such as Majorsville, we've not yet experienced a full year's earnings run rate. Having said that, overall operating earnings for the year were down due to anticipated expense increases, pension and integrity management in particular and reduced short-term transportation revenue resulting from a lack of natural gas price volatility. Looking forward, we remain enthusiastic about NGT&S' earnings growth prospects for 2011 and beyond, driven by accretive infrastructure investments, which we expect to amount to about $200 million annually.
Turning to our third major business unit, NiSource Gas Distribution or NGD. Our NGD teams continue to execute on our strategy of combining long-term infrastructure replacement programs with complementary regulatory initiatives. 
Millions of customers are benefiting from this strategy, which includes significant revenue-producing facility modernization programs at our largest utilities: Columbia Gas of Ohio, Columbia Gas of Pennsylvania and Columbia Gas of Massachusetts. In aggregate, these programs provide NGD with an investment opportunity approaching $4.5 billion over the next 20 to 25 years. 
On the regulatory front in December, Columbia Gas of Virginia received approval from the Virginia State Corporation Commission of a unanimous settlement of its first base rate case in 12 years.  The settlement authorized a $5 million revenue increase as well as a number of rate design and other enhancements. The new rates took effect January 1st. 
And in mid-January, Columbia Gas of Pennsylvania filed a new rate case with the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission. That case seeks recovery of ongoing infrastructure investments, a modernized rate structure, as well as new senior citizen and energy efficiency programs. The filing seeks an annual revenue increase of about $38 million.
Finally, I'd like to briefly outline our 2011 earnings guidance and key 2010 takeaways on Slide 8 before opening the line to your questions. Based on the continued success of our balanced business strategy and the extensive array of growth investment opportunities available across all of our businesses, we remain confident that NiSource will sustainably grow long-term earnings in the range of 3% to 5% annually.
In fact, in the near term, particularly as we execute a number of regulatory initiatives, our operating earnings growth may well exceed that longer-term percentage range. 
With that in mind, we expect NiSource's 2011 net operating earnings to fall within a range of $1.25 to $1.35 per share. You should know, this is a non-GAAP range. Consistent with last year's outlook due to the unpredictability of weather and other factors, we're not providing GAAP earnings guidance. I'll also note that our 2011 guidance continues to be premised on a relatively modest and gradual economic recovery across the markets we serve.
In closing, I'd like to acknowledge our team, our customers and our many business community partners for their support and engagement during the past year. We've made significant progress on our business plan during 2010, all built on a foundation of ongoing investment across all of our companies.  
This core strategy remains unchanged for 2011, with the notable enhancement of our ability to invest in our businesses by the steps taken over the last years. And I can assure you that our investment approach will remain disciplined and straightforward, focused on meeting our customer needs while building long-term value for our shareholders.
As always, we remain committed to communicating with our stakeholders in a transparent and timely manner regarding these and all of our efforts. Ongoing updates will be provided through our analyst calls and news releases posted on NiSource.com. 
Thank you for participating today and for your continued interest and support of NiSource. Now Danielle, let's open the call to questions.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Bob, could you help give me some color with respect to where we are in the Indiana settlement with respect to? If we're looking at, I guess, new rates perhaps being effective beginning of 2012, since the IURC is going to need to approve that, does that su
componenttext: Bob, could you help give me some color with respect to where we are in the Indiana settlement with respect to? If we're looking at, I guess, new rates perhaps being effective beginning of 2012, since the IURC is going to need to approve that, does that suggest a settlement basically midyear, is that kind of the effective timing?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just the one key point on context for this case, we filed rate case two under the commission's expedited rules processing guidelines. And the commission accepted that filing under those guidelines and, in fact, has established an expedited procedural sche
componenttext: Just the one key point on context for this case, we filed rate case two under the commission's expedited rules processing guidelines. And the commission accepted that filing under those guidelines and, in fact, has established an expedited procedural schedule for the case, Paul, that would provide for a decision during the fourth quarter of 2011. So if this case is litigated, it would proceed along that schedule, and we feel confident the commission would render a decision during the fourth quarter, which would enable us to put rates into effect at the beginning of 2012. Now again, that context, our intent, our hope, our desire would be to try to settle this case. And as I've mentioned consistently, we put full court press during the first quarter into the second quarter to attempt to settle this before the other parties have to put there witnesses on the stand and subject them to cross examinations. So we're now on a window, we're engaged in the parties, and we're going to work diligently to try to settle this prior to midyear.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Bob, one other kind of question off of that. In the 2010 rate case, was all about this sort of conservation and pension and, of course, the host of more thorny issues for the 2008 case. The motion to vacate and sort of settlement discussions as it's ongoi
componenttext: Bob, one other kind of question off of that. In the 2010 rate case, was all about this sort of conservation and pension and, of course, the host of more thorny issues for the 2008 case. The motion to vacate and sort of settlement discussions as it's ongoing right now, are most of the conversations with shippers on the 2010 issues or is it still sort of looking at it more holistically, shall we say?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: More holistically in the sense that cost allocation is an issue that remains. And we've attempted in rate case to set a direction that would provide the parties an opportunity to compromise on cost allocation. But we believe that will continue to be the k
componenttext: More holistically in the sense that cost allocation is an issue that remains. And we've attempted in rate case to set a direction that would provide the parties an opportunity to compromise on cost allocation. But we believe that will continue to be the key challenge in resolving this case sooner rather than later. Just let me add, Carl, that we continue to believe that the traditional cost of service rate base sorts of issues are straight forward.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011

componenttext: And then one last question if I could, so lots of moving parts as there always are, as we look to 2011 guidance and we look to segment, clearly LDC should be doing well given some of the depreciation changes that have happened at NIPSCO gas. As we're kind of looking at the pluses and minuses that are happening, like what happened to transportation, even though we have some good demand charge addition, the O&M kind of overwhelmed at least for a little while, should we still be expecting a possible slide on a net basis in pipelines for 2011 before perhaps kicking up in 2012? I just want to be sort of on the lookout of if there's any particular unit that might, in fact, be sliding on an operating income basis.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: We expect all three units to perform well. NGT&S in particular, we expect a strong year. We have baked into the estimate of relatively conservative outlook on our optimization, short-term Transportation business at NGT&S. So we believe that, that hit is b
componenttext: We expect all three units to perform well. NGT&S in particular, we expect a strong year. We have baked into the estimate of relatively conservative outlook on our optimization, short-term Transportation business at NGT&S. So we believe that, that hit is behind us. So again, all three units, Carl, ought to be performing quite well in 2011. That's the expectation.

componenttext: If I could just ask you a couple questions, first, on the operating expenses at Gas Transmission and Storage Operation. I know you guys talked about some of the headwinds you have there. So OpEx was up I guess about $32 million year-over-year, how is that the going to trend into 2011? Should we now expect that since some of those maintenance activities are done that, that number should trend down or is it going to be relatively flat?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: We believe the core reliability and integrity management spends will be, give or take, flat year-to-year. We think some of the headwinds we had with pension expense at NGT&S, and you will recall that they're on a cash basis, they're not on a expense basis
componenttext: We believe the core reliability and integrity management spends will be, give or take, flat year-to-year. We think some of the headwinds we had with pension expense at NGT&S, and you will recall that they're on a cash basis, they're not on a expense basis and that's because of FERC treatment of pension and their rate. So again, we believe that, that will flatten out as well.

componenttext: Thanks, Bob. The accelerated depreciation resulted from the legislation passed here recently. Over the next couple of years, 2011, 2012, it's going to provide between $300 million and $400 million of benefit over the next several years, so it is a timing mechanism. You'll recall that in 2011, we get 100% bonus depreciation and in 2012, we get 50% bonus depreciation. So we've taken a rough estimate at what we believe bonus depreciation will provide to us in 2011. And that's in between $150 million and $200 million. And that is reflected in the sources and uses statement for 2011.

For guidance purposes, we're assuming that we would pull half of the forward sale down at the end of the third quarter in 2011. But it's something that we look at routinely. Having said that, we're not ignoring the performance of the MLP. We believe that it can be an attractive and useful vehicle in certain circumstances. So as our plan unfolds, we'll continue to keep it in mind.

componenttext: In terms of our need to access the debt capital markets in 2011, we don't necessarily need to do that to take care of everything we need to take care of. And I would say we don't need to access them in 2011, but we want to maintain that option to the extent we like what we're seeing in the markets, we may go ahead and take some of that 2012 maturity off the table.

componenttextpreview: But you would say $1 billion is about the downside? And again, I'm not trying to pin you too much but...
componenttext: But you would say $1 billion is about the downside? And again, I'm not trying to pin you too much but...

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, we think we're firmly within that $1 billion to $1.1 billion window. And let me, Jay, just give you a bit of additional color. Clearly, the Indiana commission's approval of the scrubber program in Indiana has tripped the wire for us to begin work on
componenttext: Yes, we think we're firmly within that $1 billion to $1.1 billion window. And let me, Jay, just give you a bit of additional color. Clearly, the Indiana commission's approval of the scrubber program in Indiana has tripped the wire for us to begin work on that project. So we're going to accelerate some of that spending to ensure that we get that scrubber place and operational by the end of 2013.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, great. Lastly, Bob, on the economy, I think one of the last question was talking about 4Q versus 3Q, which is interesting rearview mirror stuff. But I'd love your sort of feel of what the economy's suggesting to you sort of right now for the balance
componenttext: Yes, great. Lastly, Bob, on the economy, I think one of the last question was talking about 4Q versus 3Q, which is interesting rearview mirror stuff. But I'd love your sort of feel of what the economy's suggesting to you sort of right now for the balance of 2011, in particularly in Indiana where you're sitting, but as well throughout the other territories.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, we just believe it's going to be a slow, gradual recovery of the economy. We certainly observed with interest U.S. Steel's recent announcement about market conditions. And you may recall, they said while they have a good strong order book for Q1, the
componenttext: Yes, we just believe it's going to be a slow, gradual recovery of the economy. We certainly observed with interest U.S. Steel's recent announcement about market conditions. And you may recall, they said while they have a good strong order book for Q1, they were squarely in the camp of believing that the economy was going to continue to be slow and the recovery was going to be measured. So, obviously, we listened to our big customers pretty carefully and like them, we just believe it's going to be very, very gradual. And that's what the estimate reflects.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Got you. And that'd be fairly consistent across, I guess, going all the way up through Massachusetts but down all the way through Heartland, Pennsylvania.
componenttext: Got you. And that'd be fairly consistent across, I guess, going all the way up through Massachusetts but down all the way through Heartland, Pennsylvania.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ohio and PA, certainly, we see those same sorts of conditions.
componenttext: Yes, Ohio and PA, certainly, we see those same sorts of conditions.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011

componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Jonathan Lefebvre with Wells Fargo.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to touch on the load uptick in the economic recovery that you were just mentioning. And just wondering if maybe you can give us a sense for kind of, I know you have a lot of sensitivity in obviously, the steel industry. Do you have any sense f
componenttext: Just wanted to touch on the load uptick in the economic recovery that you were just mentioning. And just wondering if maybe you can give us a sense for kind of, I know you have a lot of sensitivity in obviously, the steel industry. Do you have any sense for the operating rates or utilization rates that they're running at right now? And how much further upside could we see? Just trying to help frame that up a bit.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, our sense on steel production in our areas is about 70% utilization, maybe a little bit north of that number. Again, U.S. Steel indicates that they have a pretty good order book for Q1 and then it's pretty slow after that. So decent utilization rates
componenttext: Yes, our sense on steel production in our areas is about 70% utilization, maybe a little bit north of that number. Again, U.S. Steel indicates that they have a pretty good order book for Q1 and then it's pretty slow after that. So decent utilization rates in our area.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: And where have they averaged historically?
componenttext: And where have they averaged historically?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: If you go back to 2008, 2009, they were pretty much flat out. And then, of course, I guess it was 2008 then it began declining probably as low as 50%, 60% utilization.
componenttext: If you go back to 2008, 2009, they were pretty much flat out. And then, of course, I guess it was 2008 then it began declining probably as low as 50%, 60% utilization.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011

componenttext: Got you. And is there any way to think about how that might impact if we get back up towards the 80%, 90%, how that might impact the earnings in NIPSCO?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, again, the key going forward is resolution of this new NIPSCO rate case. I mentioned cost allocation rate design, the impact of load growth will be determined by how those rates are designed.
componenttext: Well, again, the key going forward is resolution of this new NIPSCO rate case. I mentioned cost allocation rate design, the impact of load growth will be determined by how those rates are designed.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Got you, okay. And then just switching gears onto the pipes. I noticed another decrease due to short-term transportation and storage. Just wondering if maybe you can help us understand, which pipes are being impacted? And how much has that been kind of at
componenttext: Got you, okay. And then just switching gears onto the pipes. I noticed another decrease due to short-term transportation and storage. Just wondering if maybe you can help us understand, which pipes are being impacted? And how much has that been kind of at its peak and where are we today on earnings for this interruptible service?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: We call this business park and loan optimization, and Columbia Gas Transmission is the primary pipe for that activity. And historically, the business has ranged from $15 million to $20 million annually, to as high as $40 million annually. And I alluded to
componenttext: We call this business park and loan optimization, and Columbia Gas Transmission is the primary pipe for that activity. And historically, the business has ranged from $15 million to $20 million annually, to as high as $40 million annually. And I alluded to 2009, at NGT&S, we exceeded $40 million in revenue. But this market, this line of business, which is relatively small for us to hit the margin, is solely dependent on gas price volatility and more particularly what seasonal spreads are; that's how we capture the margin on this short-term park and loan activity. So 2009, we're at $40 million. 2010, that number dropped to $20 million, again, a function of price volatility. And going forward, we baked into the forecast a more modest level, in or about $20 million is what the forecast reflects.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Got you. And is that more of a seasonal spread or is that a basis spread?
componenttext: Got you. And is that more of a seasonal spread or is that a basis spread?

componenttextpreview: Seems to be a seasonal spread.
componenttext: Seems to be a seasonal spread.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Summer, winter spread.
componenttext: Summer, winter spread.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Summer, winter spread, they park the gas in our storage and then withdraw in the winter when prices are higher.
componenttext: Summer, winter spread, they park the gas in our storage and then withdraw in the winter when prices are higher.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011

componenttext: Yes, it was $1.50 in certain cases and now it's below $0.50 in certain cases, exactly.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow up on the CapEx for 2011 and going forward. You have this $1.1 billion or up to $1.1 billion in 2011, are we still thinking that a sustainable run rate going forward is $1 billion and then in some years, you'll be higher and lower? Or a
componenttext: I wanted to follow up on the CapEx for 2011 and going forward. You have this $1.1 billion or up to $1.1 billion in 2011, are we still thinking that a sustainable run rate going forward is $1 billion and then in some years, you'll be higher and lower? Or are we thinking that maybe there's an uptick even in a sustainable rate going forward?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, we still believe it's $1 billion is a representative number. But as you said, better than I did, that it could tick up, it could tick down depending on conditions. And one of the key sensitivities is can we deploy the way we believe we can deploy in t
componenttext: No, we still believe it's $1 billion is a representative number. But as you said, better than I did, that it could tick up, it could tick down depending on conditions. And one of the key sensitivities is can we deploy the way we believe we can deploy in the Marcellus region.

componenttext: Okay. And a follow-up there, do you have any update on the PENNSTAR project and what kind of interest you're seeing there?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: PENNSTAR team is actively marketing the project and so they're literally real-time discussions with a wide variety of key shippers. We expect that process to continue for the next 30 to 90 days.
componenttext: PENNSTAR team is actively marketing the project and so they're literally real-time discussions with a wide variety of key shippers. We expect that process to continue for the next 30 to 90 days.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if that moves forward, what was the in-service date, is that about at 2013?
componenttext: Okay. And if that moves forward, what was the in-service date, is that about at 2013?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Correct. We had originally talked in terms of roughly 2012, but with the softening of gas prices, we're now talking in terms of 2013. So you're spot on.
componenttext: Correct. We had originally talked in terms of roughly 2012, but with the softening of gas prices, we're now talking in terms of 2013. So you're spot on.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then switching gears to -- could you talk a little bit about in the Gas Transmission, specifically on Columbia Gulf, can you remind us what percent of contracts come up for renewal in 2011 and kind of what you baked into your outlook rega
componenttext: Okay, great. And then switching gears to -- could you talk a little bit about in the Gas Transmission, specifically on Columbia Gulf, can you remind us what percent of contracts come up for renewal in 2011 and kind of what you baked into your outlook regarding just renewal rates?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, on renewals, we expect to have strong renewals this year. We frankly don't have much coming up in 2011. 2012, 2013, we have a bigger slug of renewals due. In fact, Columbia Gas of Ohio has a fairly significant contract position that's due for renewal
componenttext: Yes, on renewals, we expect to have strong renewals this year. We frankly don't have much coming up in 2011. 2012, 2013, we have a bigger slug of renewals due. In fact, Columbia Gas of Ohio has a fairly significant contract position that's due for renewal in 2012, '13. And right now, the outlook assumes that we have no significant turn back, we have no significant reduction in rate levels. And one thing I would point out when you look at throughput, Columbia Gulf throughput has held up good during 2010. It was down during the first half and recovered quite well. So that's number one. Number two, we've had a couple of recent renewals that again would indicate that Columbia Gulf is going to be very competitive, and we feel good about the position of that pipeline.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Ben Sung with Luminus Management.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Ben Sung with Luminus Management.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Is there much going on, on the legislative front in Indiana?
componenttext: Is there much going on, on the legislative front in Indiana?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's an active session in the legislature. You may recall that current governor, Mitch Daniels, filed two years of office. This election cycle gave him not only a Republican Senate but a Republican House. So he has an aggressive agenda lined up to complet
componenttext: It's an active session in the legislature. You may recall that current governor, Mitch Daniels, filed two years of office. This election cycle gave him not only a Republican Senate but a Republican House. So he has an aggressive agenda lined up to complete his term as Governor. We and other utilities have been discussing legislative proposals that would help, we believe, streamline and modernize IURC regulation. Those packages are still in discussion phase and have not yet really garnered a lot of air time at the legislature at this point. But we'll continue to work on that.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011

componenttext: We'll probably going to know whether it has lags or not within the next 90 days.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011

componenttext: Just a follow-up on that Columbia Gulf question, if I understood the answer, you're not really seeing much exposure with respect to contracts that are going to be expiring and renewal in rates, am I getting that pretty?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, you do. One thing again though I just want to highlight, in 2012, 2013, we have one significant in Greenwood Columbia Gas of Ohio that needs to be dealt with. And the reason I highlight that is, it's a relatively sizable agreement. And you may know o
componenttext: Yes, you do. One thing again though I just want to highlight, in 2012, 2013, we have one significant in Greenwood Columbia Gas of Ohio that needs to be dealt with. And the reason I highlight that is, it's a relatively sizable agreement. And you may know or recall that in Ohio, we, like the other utilities, have moved to an open access auction process. And questions around capacity and lags still need to be dealt with. So again, that's more of a highlight, it's not,  we don't feel alarmed about it. And again, we believe Columbia Gulf is in great position.

componenttext: No. Columbia Gas Transmission, the big pipe, is completely sold out. We believe that status is going to continue.

componenttext: So for the next several years, it looks like we really don't have much exposure on that, unlike some of the other companies that are out there, is that correct?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: I got a couple of questions about liquidity, can you address the revolver, the renewal, the size of it, potential cost increases that you would be looking at through 2011?
componenttext: I got a couple of questions about liquidity, can you address the revolver, the renewal, the size of it, potential cost increases that you would be looking at through 2011?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: We're in the process of renewing our facility. And the size of it is going to be maintained at $1.5 billion. We're looking at a four-year renewal. You'll also be aware that the facility actually expires in July of 2011 so we are getting ahead of the curve
componenttext: We're in the process of renewing our facility. And the size of it is going to be maintained at $1.5 billion. We're looking at a four-year renewal. You'll also be aware that the facility actually expires in July of 2011 so we are getting ahead of the curve here and anticipate that we'll have that new facility closed within the first quarter. Pricing has gone up. The old facility was in LIBOR plus 50 to 60 basis point range. The new facility is in the LIBOR plus 200 basis point range.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, let me ask a question about the size of the revolver. I mean I understand the working capital needs that you have. But I mean right now your rough liquidity available is right around $400 million. Gas is relatively low at the current time. From a wo
componenttext: Well, let me ask a question about the size of the revolver. I mean I understand the working capital needs that you have. But I mean right now your rough liquidity available is right around $400 million. Gas is relatively low at the current time. From a working capital standpoint and given your credit rating and the amount of debt that you had and the issues that took place back in 2009, anything driven, any thought to increasing the size of the revolver?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. I think we're in good shape at $1.5 billion of liquidity. And I would just point out that we have moved to an auction arrangement for a percentage of the volumes in Ohio. And so over the next two to three years, we'll see probably a reduction through
componenttext: No. I think we're in good shape at $1.5 billion of liquidity. And I would just point out that we have moved to an auction arrangement for a percentage of the volumes in Ohio. And so over the next two to three years, we'll see probably a reduction through liquidity as we result of that transition. At this point though, we feel that $1 billion to $1.5 billion is adequate, and we want to maintain it there for the foreseeable future. We don't anticipate needing more liquidity than that.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2011

componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Ashar Khan with  Visium Asset Management.

componenttext: Bob, can you just highlight what makes you go in the upper end of the range for '11 as we look through the year? componenttext: The economy would be the key driver to push us up, would be one. Two, we talked about park and loan optimization activity. So if seasonal spreads expanded materially, and they don't have to expand materially, those two would be the key drivers that might push us in a positive fashion.

componenttext: Yes. But again, on the gas side, you'll recall, many of our LDCs have mitigated that loss through rate design. When you're running your model, you have to take that into account. Ohio being a great example where there's straight fixed variable rate design.

componenttext: It's not material. It wouldn't move the needle very much. Randy can get to a better number, a thumbnail sort of number, but it really wouldn't drive the earnings. componenttext: Right, Paul, for return on assets, we're still assuming 8.75% for 2011 and beyond. And our discount rate at year end was 5%. I would point out that the year, as you know, was pretty good in 2010, and we were in the 13% to 14% return overall on our pension, so that helped.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Q1 2011 NiSource Earnings Conference Call. My name is Laura and I'll be your operator today. [Operator Instructions]  I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Mr. Glen Ketterin
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Q1 2011 NiSource Earnings Conference Call. My name is Laura and I'll be your operator today. [Operator Instructions]  I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Mr. Glen Kettering, Senior Vice President of Corporate Affairs. Glen, please proceed.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning, everyone. On behalf of NiSource, I'd like to welcome you to our quarterly analyst call. Joining me this morning are Bob Skaggs, President and Chief Executive Officer; Steve Smith, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial O
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning, everyone. On behalf of NiSource, I'd like to welcome you to our quarterly analyst call. Joining me this morning are Bob Skaggs, President and Chief Executive Officer; Steve Smith, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Randy Hulen, Managing Director of Investor Relations.
As you know, the focus of today's call is to review our financial performance for the first quarter of 2011 and to provide a business update. We'll then open the call to your questions. 
At times during the call, we will refer to the supplemental slides available on our website at nisource.com. I'd like to remind all of you that some of the statements made on this conference call will be forward-looking statements. These statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed in the statement. Information concerning such risks and uncertainties is included in the MD&A and Risk Factors sections of our periodic SEC filings. And now I'll turn the call over to Bob Skaggs.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Glenn and good morning, and thank for joining us today. This morning's agenda is brief to provide us as much time as possible for questions and discussions. So first I'll touch on a few key takeaways from our first quarter performance. Next, I'll
componenttext:
Thanks, Glenn and good morning, and thank for joining us today. This morning's agenda is brief to provide us as much time as possible for questions and discussions. So first I'll touch on a few key takeaways from our first quarter performance. Next, I'll note several key highlights for NiSource in each of our business units, and then we'll open the line to your questions. 
To kick off, a few key takeaways from the first quarter. If you turn to Slide 3 in the supplemental materials, you see several headlines but the core message is this: We are on track. 
First and foremost, our numbers are on track, perhaps more so than immediately meets the eye, as I'll touch on in a moment. The strength of this year's performance if anything is obscured a bit by a few items. So again, the overriding takeaways that NiSource's regulatory, commercial and operational fundamentals are quite strong and our year-to-date performance is squarely in line with our 2011 earnings outlook. 
Second, our Indiana strategy is on track. As you know, a key focus for our NIPSCO team is successful resolution of our 2010 electric rate case. That case is moving forward, and we still expect resolution at the end of the year or early next year. 
Third, we're also building on our track record of successful regulatory and infrastructure modernization programs at our gas utilities. These efforts are generating positive results this year and will continue to build long-term shareholder and customer value going forward. 
And finally, we remain on track with our growth investments at our Gas Pipeline and Storage business, with a particular emphasis on those projects that leverage our very attractive footprint in our Marcellus Shale region. 
Underpinning all these efforts is our commitment to effective financial management and a strong liquidity profile is demonstrated our a new $1.5 billion 4-year revolving credit facility that we closed in early March. 
So the 10-second soundbite is this: NiSource is on track to deliver on a robust agenda of infrastructure investments paired with exceptional commercial and regulatory execution. 
With that preface, let's now take a closer look at the quarter, starting with our overall financial highlights on Slide 4. 
As you can see, we delivered first quarter net operating earnings, non-GAAP, of about $202 million, or $0.72 per share. As I mentioned a moment ago, the year-over-year comparison is skewed a bit by 3 items: first, the quarter's revenues were reduced almost $20 million as a result of redesign changes under last year's favorable NIPSCO gas rate case settlement. Notably, those revenue impacts will be mitigated through the course of the year. Second, during the quarter, we reported a nonrecurring $8 million accounting charge related to environmental costs at NIPSCO. And third, in last year's first quarter, we recognized revenues of about $8 million, associated with the sale of stored gas. 
When you take these items into consideration, considered strong fundamentals posted for the quarter, you get a clear picture of the ongoing earnings momentum we are building here at NiSource. 
With that, let's dive into our individual business unit results, starting with Indiana and our Electric business on Slide 5. 
Our Indiana team continues to make significant progress on our efforts to improve performance, services and rates, and restore NIPSCO's earnings to an appropriate level. From a financial standpoint, NIPSCO electric reported first quarter operating earnings of about $42 million, compared to $46 million for the same period in 2010. Notably, NIPSCO saw an increase in its industrial margins and usage to help drive a net revenue increase of about $9 million, excluding trackers. 
Operating expenses increased by about $13 million over last year's levels. However, that jump was due to the environmental charge that I mentioned a moment ago. On the regulatory front, NIPSCO remains on track to establish electric base rates by late 2011 or early 2012. While the formal rate case process continues to move forward, NIPSCO is actively engaged in settlement discussions with all of its stakeholders. Once resolved, we're confident the case will position the company for ongoing growth for continued customer focus investments in service, reliability and environmental infrastructure. 
Speaking of investments, NIPSCO is moving ahead on installation of a new Flue Gas Desulfurization or FGD unit at our Schahfer Generating Station. Preliminary engineering is complete, and crews have prepped the site and started construction. If you recall, this is the first of a number of FGD units planned across NIPSCO's systems. These investments, more than $600 million over 6 to 8 years, will strengthen earnings while creating hundreds of project-related jobs and improving the environment and economic vitality of the region. Together, these new units will reduce SOx emissions on an additional 80% beyond current levels. 
Let's now shift to our Gas Distribution group on Slide 6. 
Our gas distribution operating earnings for the quarter were about $237 million, compared to about $235 million during the same period in 2010. As I noted earlier, there's a bit of noise, net revenues excluding trackers were down due to the change in NIPSCO's gas rate design, as were expenses. 
On the Investment front, Columbia Gas Kentucky, Columbia Gas of Massachusetts, Columbia Gas of Ohio, and Columbia Gas of Pennsylvania all continue to advance their significant infrastructure modernization programs during the first quarter. These ongoing programs, which began more than 3 years, proactively and systemically replaced portions of our system to ensure continued reliable and efficient service, at the same time, growing earnings. As we continue to pair these programs with complementary regulatory activity, in fact, just lastly, we received approval from the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio on our most recent filing to recover costs associated with our infrastructure replacement and energy efficiency programs which will increase yearly revenues by about $24 million effective May 1. And in Pennsylvania, our team is advancing a base rate case filed in January, seeking enhanced revenues of about $38 million. The rate case is paired with an improved rate design, and new programs to help senior citizens and others better manage their energy costs. We expect to resolve that case by year's end. 
Without question, we believe the strong focus on infrastructure, modernization in our utilities, along with appropriate regulatory treatment, will benefit our customers and communities, as well as NiSource's shareholders for decades to come. 
Let's now take a look at our NiSource Gas Transmission and Storage Operations, highlighted on Slide 7. 
Here the team's focus continues to be on market-driven growth projects, with particular emphasis on our extensive opportunities in the Marcellus Shale region. From an earnings standpoint, the NGT&S team generated operating earnings of about $119 million in the first quarter, compared to about $126 million in 2010. Net revenues were relatively flat for the quarter, as a result of last year's native storage gas sales. Operating expenses were up only about $3 million. 
Commercially, our NGT&S team continues to aggressively pursue inventory growth projects, ranging from traditional transportation and storage services, to power generation, supply aggregation, and other Marcellus production-related projects. Some of our other near-term Marcellus investments includes the Clendenin and Smithfield projects, Line WB, and the Southern Appalachia project. Together these projects will generate about half a a BCF per day of new firm transportation capacity. 
Also driven by increased Marcellus production, Millennium Pipeline completed a binding open season for proposed mainline expansion projects to provide incremental firm transportation capacity to northeast markets. Notably, prior to the season, the company executed binding precedent agreements with 2 anchor shippers. 
We are also advancing the new power generation project in the mid-Atlantic region. Although we can't share specific details at this time, it's clear the power generation market has real potential for us, given our strategic footprint between major generation hubs and the Marcellus Shale region. You'll soon see our birth certification filing for this power gen [generation] project. On the regulatory front, Columbia Gulf 2010 $50 million general rate case moved forward with the company placing new rates into effect subject to refund on May 1. Columbia Gulf and the parties to the case are actively engaged in discussions to resolve the case. 
As you can see, the NGT&S team continues to execute on its strategy of maximizing the value of its current asset base and capturing disciplined, low-risk, high-value growth opportunities.
To wrap up, 2 key points. First, we are squarely in line with our expectations and remain on track to meet demand operating earnings guidance of $1.25 to $1.35 per share, non-GAAP, for 2011. Second, we remain confident that NiSource will sustainably grow long-term earnings in the range of 3% to 5% annually, perhaps a bit more in the near term, so we execute on our Indiana business and regulatory agenda. 
As always, we'll communicate with you and all our stakeholders in a transparent and timely manner regarding these and all of our efforts through our analyst calls and news releases posted on nisource.com. Thank you for participating today, and for your ongoing interest and support of NiSource. Laura, let's now open the call to questions.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Could you maybe give us some milestones to look for in the potential settlement in the Indiana electric case?
componenttext: Could you maybe give us some milestones to look for in the potential settlement in the Indiana electric case?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, Paul. Maybe just a pressing comments or two. As I mentioned in the prepared remarks, we are active in settlement discussions. We are in the midst of around one-on-one discussions, small group discussions. The discussions have gone according to plan.
componenttext: Sure, Paul. Maybe just a pressing comments or two. As I mentioned in the prepared remarks, we are active in settlement discussions. We are in the midst of around one-on-one discussions, small group discussions. The discussions have gone according to plan. As you've heard me comment on several occasions, this is going to require concerted, concentrated efforts. But so far, so good. Process-wise, we believe we're still up in that sweet spot or that window of time where we believe we can reach a resolution. There's another round of evidenciary hearings scheduled for mid-month. That will again involve NIPSCO witnesses talking about comps allocation, rate design, and the like. The intervener stakeholders are then slated to present their testimony. I believe it's in August, give or take, Paul. So we believe between now and August, Labor Day, we have that window of opportunity to work with stakeholders and they continue to be responsive, constructive and we are working hard at achieving that settlement.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess over the last couple of months, have you got more or less optimistic about the prospects of the settlement?
componenttext: I guess over the last couple of months, have you got more or less optimistic about the prospects of the settlement?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: To stay very balanced about the prospects of settlement, as Ken here said, this case is challenging because it involves cost allocation which requires a shifting of dollars among customer classes. And again, that's heavy lifting. So realistic approach to
componenttext: To stay very balanced about the prospects of settlement, as Ken here said, this case is challenging because it involves cost allocation which requires a shifting of dollars among customer classes. And again, that's heavy lifting. So realistic approach to this, we have a fair shot at getting a summon. We're approaching that creatively. And still relatively optimistic. I've also said that the second track of this proceeding is litigation. We feel very, very good about that track, we feel very, very good about our position. I would note that we had just seen the Commission issue a fairly significant rate decision in a vectoring case. We believe that decision is instructive, constructive and frankly, helpful to our litigation decision. So we go down both tracks in a realistic and concerted effort, Paul.

componenttext: Yes. As I mentioned, those rates went to effect, such rates, on May 1. Like Columbia Gas Transmission, the interstate pipeline is primarily a fixed to variable rate design. So once those rates are, they have gone into effect, but once they are deemed just and reasonable, we collect this on a fixed to variable rate bases, so they are spread fairly evenly throughout the year.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 03, 2011

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jay Dobson from Wunderlich.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. For a start off, on industrial sales particularly in the electric side, I know you got a lot of concentration there, but 20 points, 3% increase in the quarter is pretty healthy growth. Just give us an idea of what you're seeing on t
componenttext: A couple of questions. For a start off, on industrial sales particularly in the electric side, I know you got a lot of concentration there, but 20 points, 3% increase in the quarter is pretty healthy growth. Just give us an idea of what you're seeing on the industrial side certainly after addressing electric and low you think on the gas side of the low concentration there?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me start on the electric side. As you observed, the numbers are relatively strong. They're certainly being led by steel manufacturers in the region. James, I'm sure you've seen some of the announcements from U.S. Steel and Mills about relatively
componenttext: Yes, let me start on the electric side. As you observed, the numbers are relatively strong. They're certainly being led by steel manufacturers in the region. James, I'm sure you've seen some of the announcements from U.S. Steel and Mills about relatively bullish outlook on demand through the first 3 quarters of the year. And again, those comp outlooks are being reflected in their production in this region. We mentioned that we were up considerably quarter-to-quarter. We're also up fairly strongly first quarter compared to the fourth quarter of 2010. So again we're seeing a reasonably good amount of strength in that area. I just remind you and everybody that our plan assumes a very measured, relatively slow recovery of the economy. So our outlook is not premised on a spike in demand. And we are encouraged by this but our plan is not predicated on this staying over the near-term.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Paul, I'm sorry, Jay, you also mentioned gas volumes. Then you see some pretty good strength across the footprint on industrial manufacturing throughput. So again, we are encouraged the plan is not predicated on as these sorts of increase is continuing, b
componenttext: Paul, I'm sorry, Jay, you also mentioned gas volumes. Then you see some pretty good strength across the footprint on industrial manufacturing throughput. So again, we are encouraged the plan is not predicated on as these sorts of increase is continuing, but we feel pretty good about where we stand. And just one other editorial, and I know you recognize that, the industrial side, particularly on the gas side of our business, the margins for incremental throughput are relatively thin, relatively thin. You're not going to see future comps in revenue associated with that. And also seeing on the electric side, we need the strength in the economy. We certainly enjoyed the strength in the production. But again a lot of the margin revenues are not being driven by those industrial increases.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Right, no, I absolutely recognize it as you pointed out in the slides, $9 million revenue for 20% of the industrial sales, I absolutely appreciate that. That is great. And then on just the Marcellus infrastructure, just sort of your latest thoughts, obvio
componenttext: Right, no, I absolutely recognize it as you pointed out in the slides, $9 million revenue for 20% of the industrial sales, I absolutely appreciate that. That is great. And then on just the Marcellus infrastructure, just sort of your latest thoughts, obviously, area continues to be hot and I imagine from your perspective, right with infrastructure investment opportunities. How do you see that developing over the next couple of years? Most of us will probably measured in the form of capital spending and opportunities for you all to invest and hence produce earnings and cash flow?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: We think going forward over the next couple of years, our target, we've been fairly clear, it's to spend about $200 million a year on the Marcellus region. On relatively speaking small bite-size projects that add capacity and the like. This year, we're go
componenttext: We think going forward over the next couple of years, our target, we've been fairly clear, it's to spend about $200 million a year on the Marcellus region. On relatively speaking small bite-size projects that add capacity and the like. This year, we're going to spend about $150 million in the region. We believe we are on track for that spend. And the vast majority of the spend will continue to be on the bite-size, small projects to enable the production to get to a liquid point as quickly as possible. Like you, we see the region continuing to be active, and we continue to work with the key players in the region. Range, , Mark West and others.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: That's great. And then lastly, I don't think I quite follow you on your earlier comments, Bob, that you mentioned an accounting charge of about $8 million and you put it in the environmental. I was wondering if you could give us a little insight there. I'
componenttext: That's great. And then lastly, I don't think I quite follow you on your earlier comments, Bob, that you mentioned an accounting charge of about $8 million and you put it in the environmental. I was wondering if you could give us a little insight there. I'm sure it's in the queue.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is in NIPSCO Electric. By the way, I don't believe it is. Yes, it is in the queue, sure it would be in the queue. This is in NIPSCO electric, and during a routine scrub of our regulatory assets at NIPSCO, we discovered a relatively few old and relati
componenttext: This is in NIPSCO Electric. By the way, I don't believe it is. Yes, it is in the queue, sure it would be in the queue. This is in NIPSCO electric, and during a routine scrub of our regulatory assets at NIPSCO, we discovered a relatively few old and relatively old deferrals of NIPSCO environmental cost that we just didn't believe are recoverable. And I just emphasize a couple of things. Nonrecurring, this is not a go-forward problem with environmental cost, this is not a go-forward problem with the environmental cost recovery tracker in Indiana.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 03, 2011

componenttext: So more of just a cleanup of something old?

componenttext: Yes, just a routine scrub.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes the line of Stephen Maresca from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes the line of Stephen Maresca from Morgan Stanley.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions, if I may, on the Gas Transmission and Storage. First on the quarter, and just in the earnings were down a little bit, but then you mentioned you decreased your transportation and storage services. Help me think about what's the outl
componenttext: A couple of questions, if I may, on the Gas Transmission and Storage. First on the quarter, and just in the earnings were down a little bit, but then you mentioned you decreased your transportation and storage services. Help me think about what's the outlook for that, for the remainder of this year over the next 4 quarters? And how should we think about the decrease in the quarter, I know there is a gain in the first quarter of '10, if that helps out?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good, you take a close look at the numbers. Let me give you the negatives and the positives when I think about NGT&S for the quarter and for the year. And you mentioned a couple of them. We had the storage gas sale first quarter 2010. Our Optimization bus
componenttext: Good, you take a close look at the numbers. Let me give you the negatives and the positives when I think about NGT&S for the quarter and for the year. And you mentioned a couple of them. We had the storage gas sale first quarter 2010. Our Optimization business, Park and Loan business continues to be flat or down a bit. And then there's also a interest in that occurred at Millennium as they firmed up their financing. Again, these are unusual out-of-the-ordinary sorts of occurrences I think that do skew the quarter a bit. But when you drill down and look on the NGT&S numbers, several notable pluses and takeaways that continue for the balance of the year and going forward. Number one, you'll see demand and commodity revenues are up in a very positive fashion, again reflecting projects, recon, track team, and the like. You'll also see the volumes are up considerably. And third, the underlying expense structure continues to be well-managed. And then last but not least, beginning in May we have the lift from the Columbia Gulf rate cas. We'll reserve a portion of that case, but nonetheless, we have a significant lift in the end. So again when you cut through the noise and look at the key fundamentals, demand, commodity, volumes, expenses, regulatory activity and then the projects that we're working on, we feel very good about NGT&S and where it stands.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, that was helpful. Switching, same segment but intensive new growth outlook, and you talked about 150 this year, 200 as a target annually in Marcellus region. What sort of needs are you seeing from producers right now? Is it more on the strict pipe s
componenttext: Okay, that was helpful. Switching, same segment but intensive new growth outlook, and you talked about 150 this year, 200 as a target annually in Marcellus region. What sort of needs are you seeing from producers right now? Is it more on the strict pipe side or would you consider thinking about getting into more of a liquid opportunity, if that arose? And how would contracts be? Are they still favorable, is there still enough demand to get commitments?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, on the last one, we believe the market is still favorable to get commitments in structure arrangements that we feel need our risk profile. In the way of what the producers are looking for, and you touched on most of those, but it's a gathering quasi-
componenttext: Yes, on the last one, we believe the market is still favorable to get commitments in structure arrangements that we feel need our risk profile. In the way of what the producers are looking for, and you touched on most of those, but it's a gathering quasi-gathering, deep bottlenecking, getting casted point to liquid points where they can monetize as quickly and effectively as they can. We do believe that there will be opportunities for processing and the like, liquid handling and the like. That hasn't necessarily been our sweet spot, but we consider opportunities to enable or deleverage ongoing investments in the areas, sure. But they are going to have to meet our risk return profile, and again, we do believe there are opportunities in that region. We've said this consistently, we don't see production levels at levels that would support large-scale, long-line expansion projects. We do believe though as production grows, and we have more critical mass, the gas will go further downstream, we'll seek markets that will require larger-scale investments. But for the time-being, the bite-size, access providing sorts of projects, that's where we'll continue to focus.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Carl Kirst from BMO Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Carl Kirst from BMO Capital.

headline: NiSource Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Actually, this -- Bob, if I could just key off the last comment you made. Most of my questions have been answered here. In recognizing that you guys are speaking at LDC forums and trade group meetings all the time. But there was one media article that ran
componenttext: Actually, this -- Bob, if I could just key off the last comment you made. Most of my questions have been answered here. In recognizing that you guys are speaking at LDC forums and trade group meetings all the time. But there was one media article that ran about perhaps -- you guys are looking at a mid-Atlantic pipeline, which if I kind of go into memory, although I don't remember the name right, it looks like the old Patriot proposal from way back when? How serious is that? I mean, at this stage, is this something where we could in fact be looking at a new pipeline to serve mid-Atlantic generation, I guess feeding mid-continent shale gas? Or is that something we should be putting more in the 3-, 4-, 5-year bucket?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: It would be the latter sort of consideration. Karl, maybe I could just give you a bit of an overview and perspective for management on growth projects at NGT&S. Without a doubt, without a question, the primary focus is going to be leveraging this Marcellu
componenttext: It would be the latter sort of consideration. Karl, maybe I could just give you a bit of an overview and perspective for management on growth projects at NGT&S. Without a doubt, without a question, the primary focus is going to be leveraging this Marcellus opportunity that we have. That's Job 1, 2 and 3. And as you recognize, that's a supply push, a producer push sort of opportunity. We're not going to predicate our entire growth on supply push, so we are looking for demand opportunities on-system, adjacent to the system. So we are going to continue to look at demand opportunities. I mentioned one power generation project that we are actively advancing. That's a good example of continued focus on the demand side of the market. The opportunity that you mentioned, it's called Canasom[ph], and again, it represents demand-focused opportunity for us. It's a potential opportunity to provide another outlet to another market for Marcellus gas. As you suggested, this project is in the early, early stage of development. So that's one of the reasons it's not reflected in our formal comments today, because we're actively working the markets to determine whether this has a real potential for us. So, that's the overview on where we stand. This project is a long-term sort of look, and I just closed up by saying our tenants for growth remain the same. And anything we do is going to be focused, we're going to be disciplined, project -- our projects will be 100% contracted for, as you know, we try to actively risk manage projects through the use of structured arrangements, joint venture partners, or whatever. So a little bit of overview, little bit of color on how we regard demand projects.

componenttext: I appreciate that, thank you for the color. Maybe one other question on the pipes and this kind of speaks to Millennium. And I guess I'm also trying to just brainstorm and think about this in terms of the PENNSTAR pipeline which goes into Millennium, because our understanding is that well's coming out in northeast Pennsylvania is so large that even Millennium is now kind of getting backed up for your open season. Is PENNSTAR partly predicated on the fact of getting more capacity on Millennium?

headline: NiSource Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: We certainly believe that would help. But maybe I'd just get to the Millennium point. The timing of the expansion, 12 to 24 months is the window for this expansion. We do believe that there are additional opportunities to effectuate very economic expansio
componenttext: We certainly believe that would help. But maybe I'd just get to the Millennium point. The timing of the expansion, 12 to 24 months is the window for this expansion. We do believe that there are additional opportunities to effectuate very economic expansions of Millennium. So we believe, down the road, there could be additional phases, and so consider this may be Phase I of that expansion. To PENNSTAR, we've been consistent in saying we believe the 2014 project, part of the softening of gas prices has moved that back a year. So clearly, opportunities for additional capacity on Millennium, I think, enhance the position of PENNSTAR.
